Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Last chapter mainly concerns with reducing subspace problem of multiplication operators M
B induced by finite Blaschke products B. This chapter still focuses on the same theme, whereas the symbol B is replaced with a thin Blaschke product. In Chap. 3
it was shown that the geometric property of this symbol B is a key to the study of the abelian property of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
. However, the geometry of thin Blaschke products is far more complicated than that of finite Blaschke products.

Body.Para:
Last chapter mainly concerns with reducing subspace problem of multiplication operators M
B induced by finite Blaschke products B. This chapter still focuses on the same theme, whereas the symbol B is replaced with a thin Blaschke product. In Chap. 3
it was shown that the geometric property of this symbol B is a key to the study of the abelian property of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
. However, the geometry of thin Blaschke products is far more complicated than that of finite Blaschke products.

Geometry of thin Blaschke products will be the main focus of this chapter. The techniques of local inverse and analytic continuation prove useful, along with a solid treatise of function theory. Finite Blaschke products and thin Blaschke products are a curious pair in that both the thin Blaschke product B and its related Riemann surface S
B have nice geometric structures. In this book, a Riemann surface is a complex manifold of complex dimension 1, not necessarily connected. Also, we give a representation of those operators in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
for such thin Blaschke products B. Based on this representation, a geometric characterization is obtained for M
B having a nontrivial reducing subspace. Furthermore, it is shown that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is always abelian. In addition, for “most” thin Blaschke products B, M
B has no nontrivial reducing subspace and such a function B is constructed. It is remarkable that this phenomenon never happens in the case of a finite Blaschke product. This reveals some differences between the geometries of thin and finite Blaschke products. As a further application of the methods, it is shown that for finite Blaschke products B, M
B usually has exactly two minimal reducing subspaces.
This chapter is mainly based on Guo and Huang’s paper [GH4].

Section1.Heading: Properties of Thin Blaschke Products
Section1.Para: In this section, it is shown that each thin Blaschke product is a branched covering map, and some properties are obtained.

Recall that a thin Blaschke product is a Blaschke product whose zero sequence {z
n } of B satisfies
$$\displaystyle{\lim _{k\rightarrow \infty }\prod _{j\geq 1,j\neq k}d(z_{j},z_{k}) = 1.}$$
Below, we denote by
$$\Delta (z,r)$$
the pseudohyperbolic disk centered at z with radius r, that is
$$\displaystyle{\Delta (z,r) =\{ w \in \mathbb{D}: \vert \frac{z - w} {1 -\overline{z}w}\vert <r\}.}$$
As done in Chap. 4
, for a Blaschke product B we denote the critical value set
$$\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}_{B} =\{ B(z): z \in \mathbb{D}\ \mathrm{and}\ B^{{\prime}}(z) = 0\},}$$
where B
′ denotes the derivative of B. Let Z(B) and Z(B
′ ) denote the zero sets of B and B
′ , respectively. We have the following proposition.

Para.Emphasis: Let B be a thin Blaschke product, then both

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para: The proof is divided into two parts.

First we will prove that the critical value set
$$\mathcal{E}_{B}$$
is discrete in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
.

It suffices to show that for any r ∈ (0, 1), each
$$w \in r\mathbb{D}$$
is not an accumulation point of
$$\mathcal{E}_{B}$$
. To see this, we first show that
$$\forall \varepsilon> 0$$
, except for finitely many n,
$$B\vert _{\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon )}$$
is univalent, and hence B
′ has no zero point on
$$\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon )$$
. The reasoning is as follows. Put
$$\displaystyle{g_{n} = B \circ \varphi _{z_{n}},}$$
and it is easy to verify that 5.1
$$\displaystyle{ \lim _{n\rightarrow \infty }\vert g_{n}^{{\prime}}(0)\vert =\lim _{ n\rightarrow \infty }\prod _{j\geq 1,j\neq n}d(z_{j},z_{n}) = 1. }$$
A theorem in [Ne, p. 171, Exercise 5] states that, if f is a holomorphic function from
$$\mathbb{D}$$
to
$$\mathbb{D}$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{f(0) = 0\ \ \mathrm{and}\ \ \vert f^{{\prime}}(0)\vert = a,}$$
then f is univalent in
$$t\mathbb{D}$$
with
$$t \equiv t(a) = \frac{a} {1+\sqrt{1-a^{2}}}.$$
Thus, each g
n is univalent on
$$t(\vert g_{n}^{{\prime}}(0)\vert )\mathbb{D}$$
. By (5.1) there is some natural number N 0 such that
$$\displaystyle{t(\vert g_{n}^{{\prime}}(0)\vert )>\varepsilon,\ n \geq N_{ 0}.}$$
Thus, for all n ≥ N 0, g
n are univalent on
$$\varepsilon \mathbb{D}$$
; that is, B is univalent on
$$\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon )$$
.

Now write
$$\delta = \frac{1+r} {2}$$
, and by Proposition 2.1.9
there exists an
$$\varepsilon \in (0,1)$$
such that | B(z) | ≥ δ > r whenever
$$d(z,z_{n}) \geq \varepsilon$$
for all n. Thus | B(z) | ≤ r only if
$$d(z,z_{n}) \leq \varepsilon$$
for some n. Also note that B is univalent on
$$\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon )$$
for n ≥ N 0, and then
$$Z(B^{{\prime}}) \cap B^{-1}(r\overline{\mathbb{D}})$$
is necessarily contained in a compact subset K of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, where
$$\displaystyle{K \triangleq \bigcup _{1\leq n<N_{0}}\overline{\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon )}.}$$
For any
$$w \in r\mathbb{D}$$
, if w were an accumulation point of
$$\mathcal{E}_{B}$$
, then there would be a sequence {λ
n } in K satisfying B
′ (λ
n ) = 0 and
$$\lim \limits _{n\rightarrow \infty }B(\lambda _{n}) = w.$$
Without loss of generality, we may assume that {λ
n } converges to some point in K. SinceB
′ (λ
n ) = 0, B
′ was identically zero on
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, and then B was a constant. This is a contradiction. Therefore,
$$\mathcal{E}_{B} \cap r\mathbb{D}$$
has no accumulation point. By the arbitrariness of r,
$$\mathcal{E}_{B}$$
is discrete in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
.

Next we show that
$$B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
is discrete in the open unit disk; equivalently,
$$B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B}) \cap r\mathbb{D}$$
is finite for any 0 < r < 1.

Now fix such an r. The discrete property of
$$\mathcal{E}_{B}$$
shows that
$$B(r\mathbb{D}) \cap \mathcal{E}_{B}$$
is finite, and hence
$$B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B}) \cap r\mathbb{D}$$
is discrete. By arbitrariness of r,
$$B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
is discrete in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, as desired. The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para:
Later, one will see that Z(B
′ ) always contains infinite points, say
$$w_{1},\cdots \,,w_{n},\cdots$$
. Since
$$\mathcal{E}_{B}$$
is discrete in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
,
$$\lim \limits _{n\rightarrow \infty }\vert B(w_{n})\vert = 1$$
.
Below, it will be shown that each thin Blaschke product is a branched covering map. First we need a lemma [GH4] of independent interest.

Para.Emphasis: Suppose ϕ is a holomorphic function over

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
First we show that
$$\phi \vert _{\Delta _{0}}: \Delta _{0} \rightarrow \Delta$$
is a proper map. To see this, assume conversely that there is a sequence {z
n } in
$$\Delta _{0}$$
with no limit point in
$$\Delta _{0}$$
, such that ϕ(z
n ) has a limit point
$$w_{0} \in \Delta$$
. Without loss of generality, assume that {z
n } converges to some
$$z_{0} \in \partial \Delta _{0}$$
and
$$\displaystyle{\lim _{n\rightarrow \infty }\phi (z_{n}) = w_{0}.}$$
Since
$$\overline{\Delta _{0}} \subseteq \mathbb{D}$$
,
$$z_{0} \in \mathbb{D}$$
. Then by continuity of ϕ, ϕ(z 0) = w 0, which shows that there is a connected neighborhood
$$\Delta _{1}$$
of z 0 such that
$$\Delta _{1} \subseteq \phi ^{-1}(\Delta )$$
. Note that
$$\Delta _{0} \subsetneq \Delta _{0} \cup \Delta _{1}$$
, which is a contradiction to the assumption that
$$\Delta _{0}$$
is a component of
$$\phi ^{-1}(\Delta )$$
. Therefore,
$$\phi \vert _{\Delta _{0}}: \Delta _{0} \rightarrow \Delta$$
is a proper map.

Next we show that
$$\phi \vert _{\Delta _{0}}: \Delta _{0} \rightarrow \Delta$$
is onto. Otherwise, there is a point
$$w_{1} \in \Delta -\phi (\Delta _{0}).$$
Since
$$\Delta$$
is connected, then there is a path
$$l: [0,1] \rightarrow \Delta$$
such that
$$l(0) \in \phi (\Delta _{0})$$
and l(1) = w 1. Let t 0 be the supremum of
$$\displaystyle{\{s \in [0,1];l(t) \in \phi (\Delta _{0})\mathrm{\ for\,all\ }t \in [0,s]\}.}$$
Write w 2 = l(t 0). By an argument of analysis, we have
$$w_{2} \in \partial \phi (\Delta _{0})$$
. Thus, there is a sequence {z
n
′ } in
$$\Delta _{0}$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{\lim _{n\rightarrow \infty }\phi (z_{n}^{{\prime}}) = w_{ 2}.}$$
Since
$$w_{2} \in \partial \phi (\Delta _{0})$$
, it follows that {z
n
′ } has no limit point in
$$\Delta _{0}$$
. But {ϕ(z
n
′ )} has a limit point
$$w_{2} \in \Delta$$
, which is a contradiction to the statement that
$$\phi \vert _{\Delta _{0}}: \Delta _{0} \rightarrow \Delta$$
is a proper map. Therefore,
$$\phi \vert _{\Delta _{0}}: \Delta _{0} \rightarrow \Delta$$
is onto. □

Para.Emphasis: All thin Blaschke products are branched covering maps.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para: The following proof is from [GH4].

Suppose B is a thin Blaschke product with its zero sequence {z
n }. By Proposition 2.1.8
,
$$B(\mathbb{D}) = \mathbb{D}$$
. Now we will show that
$$B: \mathbb{D} \rightarrow \mathbb{D}$$
is a branched covering map. For each
$$z \in \mathbb{D}$$
, set
$$\delta = \dfrac{1 + \vert z\vert } {2}$$
. Clearly,
$$z \in \Delta (0,\delta ).$$
To finish the proof, we must show that each connected component
$$\mathcal{J}$$
of
$$B^{-1}(\Delta (0,\delta ))$$
maps onto
$$\Delta (0,\delta )$$
by a proper map, namely, by the restriction
$$B\vert _{\mathcal{J}}$$
of B on
$$\mathcal{J}$$
.

To see this, note that by Proposition 2.1.9
, there is an
$$\varepsilon \in (0,1)$$
such that 5.2
$$\displaystyle{ B^{-1}(\Delta (0,\delta )) \subseteq \bigcup _{ n}\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon ). }$$
We first study when two pseudohyperbolic disks
$$\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon )$$
and
$$\Delta (z_{k},\varepsilon )$$
have a common point. If
$$\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon ) \cap \Delta (z_{k},\varepsilon )$$
contains a point, say z
′ , then by Garnett [Ga, p. 4, Lemma 1.4] 5.3
$$\displaystyle{ d(z_{n},z_{k}) \leq \frac{d(z_{n},z^{{\prime}}) + d(z^{{\prime}},z_{k})} {1 + d(z_{n},z^{{\prime}})d(z^{{\prime}},z_{k})} \leq d_{\varepsilon }, }$$
where
$$\displaystyle{d_{\varepsilon } =\max \{ \frac{x + y} {1 + xy}: 0 \leq x,y \leq \varepsilon \}<1.}$$
By the definition of thin Blaschke product, it is clear that
$$\displaystyle{\lim _{n\rightarrow \infty }\inf _{k\neq n}d(z_{n},z_{k}) = 1.}$$
This, combined with (5.3), shows that there is a positive integer N 0 such that
$$\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon ) \cap \Delta (z_{k},\varepsilon )$$
is empty whenever n ≥ N 0 and k ≠ n. Therefore, by (5.2) the closure of each component of
$$B^{-1}(\Delta (0,\delta ))$$
is contained in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. Applying Lemma 5.1.2 shows that the restriction of B on each connected component of
$$B^{-1}(\Delta (0,\delta ))$$
is a proper map onto
$$\Delta (0,\delta )$$
. The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para:
Thin Blaschke products share some good properties. For example, Lemma 5.1.2 states that the inverse image of the critical value set of a thin Blaschke product is discrete. Under some mild condition, the product of two thin Blaschke products is also a thin Blaschke product. Furthermore, we restate Proposition 2.1.8
as follows.

Para.Emphasis: Let B be a thin Blaschke product. Then the following hold:
can be achieved for infinitely many times by B.
∘ B is a thin Blaschke product.

Section1.Heading:
Representation for Operators in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
Section1.Para:
This section will apply the method of Sect. 4.3
in Chap. 4
to give a representation for those operators in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
, where B is a thin Blaschke product. By using the techniques of analytic continuation and local inverse (see Sect. 2.3
), we provide a sufficient condition for when
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial.

For a thin or finite Blaschke product B,
$$\mathcal{E}_{B}$$
always denotes its critical value set. As done in [T1, T2] and [DSZ], we set
$$\displaystyle{E = \mathbb{D} - B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{ B}).}$$
By Proposition 5.1.1, E is a connected open set.

Before continuing, let us make an observation. For an interpolating Blaschke product ϕ, by Garnett [Ga, p. 395, Lemma 1.4] there is an r ∈ (0, 1) such that
$$\phi ^{-1}(r\mathbb{D})$$
equals the disjoint union of domains V
i (i = 0, 1, ⋯ ), and
$$\phi \vert _{V _{i}}: V _{i} \rightarrow r\mathbb{D}$$
is biholomorphic for each i. Define biholomorphic maps ρ
i : V 0 → V
i by setting
$$\displaystyle{\rho _{i} =\phi \vert _{V _{i}}^{-1} \circ \phi \vert _{ V _{0}},}$$
and clearly
$$\phi \circ \rho _{i}\vert _{V _{0}} =\phi \vert _{V _{0}}.$$
That is, ρ
i are local inverses of ϕ on V 0. Now for any fixed point z 0 ∈ E, write λ = B(z 0) and consider ϕ = φ
λ ∘ B. Proposition 5.1.4 implies that ϕ is an interpolating Blaschke product. This observation soon leads to the following.

Para.Emphasis: Let B be a thin Blaschke product. For each z
∈ E, there always exists a neighborhood V of z
and a sequence of holomorphic functions
are local inverses of B on V, i.e. B ∘ρ
In this case, we say that V admits a complete local inverse

Section1.Para:
Note that in Lemma 5.2.1, ρ
i (V ) ∩ρ
j (V ) is empty if i ≠ j. Throughout this chapter, ρ 0 always denotes the identity map, i.e. ρ 0(z) = z, z ∈ V.

By applying Lemma 5.2.1, Guo and Huang [GH4] obtained a local representation of operators S in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
as follows.

Para.Emphasis: Let B be a thin Blaschke product. For each z
∈ E, there always exists a neighborhood V of z
and a sequence of holomorphic functions
on V satisfying the conditions in Lemma
. Furthermore, for each operator S in

Equation.EquationSource: $$\displaystyle{ Sh(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z),\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in V. }$$

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
The idea of the proof comes from [GH2]. For each z 0 ∈ E, let V be a neighborhood of z 0 as in Lemma 5.2.1. Without loss of generality, we may assume that V is a disk and rewrite
$$\Delta$$
for V. Then by Lemma 5.2.1,
$$\displaystyle{B^{-1}(B(\Delta )) =\bigsqcup _{ k}\rho _{k}(\Delta ).}$$
By Proposition 5.1.1
$$B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
is discrete in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, and then we may require that
$$\Delta \cap B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
is empty (otherwise, one can shrink
$$\Delta$$
).

For each local inverse ρ
k of B, define
$$U_{\rho _{k}}: L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}) \rightarrow L_{a}^{2}(\Delta )$$
by
$$\displaystyle{U_{\rho _{k}}h(z) = h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\,\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z),z \in \Delta,\,h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}).}$$
For each
$$w \in \Delta$$
, set
$$\displaystyle{\pi _{w}: h\mapsto \{U_{\rho _{k}}h(w)\},\,h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}).}$$
As will be soon seen, each π
w is a bounded operator from the Bergman space to l 2. In fact, we have the following.

FormalPara.Heading: Claim
FormalPara.Para:
The sequence
$$\{U_{\rho _{k}}h\}$$
is a square-summable sequence of
$$L_{a}^{2}(\Delta )$$
-functions for any
$$h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
. Consequently, for any
$$\{c_{k}\} \in l^{2}$$
,
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}U_{\rho _{k}}h(z),z \in \mathbb{D}}$$
converges uniformly on each compact subset of
$$\Delta$$
, and hence it is holomorphic in
$$\Delta$$
.

Section1.Para:
To see this, note that
$$\displaystyle{\int _{\Delta }\vert U_{\rho _{k}}h(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) =\int _{ \Delta }\vert h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\,\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) =\int _{\rho _{ k}(\Delta )}\vert h(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z),}$$

which implies that
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }\int _{ \Delta }\vert U_{\rho _{k}}h(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) =\int _{\bigsqcup _{ k\geq 0}\rho _{k}(\Delta )}\vert h(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) \leq \int _{ \mathbb{D}}\vert h(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) <\infty.}$$
Therefore,
$$\{U_{\rho _{k}}h\}$$
is a square-summable sequence of
$$L_{a}^{2}(\Delta )$$
. Also note that
$$\displaystyle{\{U_{\rho _{k}}h(w)\} =\{\langle U_{\rho _{k}}h,G_{w}\rangle \},\,w \in \Delta,}$$
where G
w denotes the reproducing kernel at w in
$$L_{a}^{2}(\Delta )$$
. Then for each
$$w \in \Delta,$$
π
w defines a bounded operator from the Bergman space to l 2. The proof of the claim is complete.

To show Lemma 5.2.2, we first consider the case of S being a unitary operator in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B).$$
In this case, we will show that there is a unique operator W: l 2 → l 2 such that 5.5
$$\displaystyle{ W\pi _{w}(h) =\pi _{w}(Sh),\ h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\ w \in \Delta. }$$
This W is necessarily unitary.

Once (5.5) is proved, we can prove (5.4) as follows. In fact, recall that ρ 0(z) = z and
$$U_{\rho _{0}} = I$$
. Denote the first row of the matrix W by {c
k } and expanding (5.5) yields 5.6
$$\displaystyle{ Sh(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}U_{\rho _{k}}h(z),\ h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in \Delta. }$$
By Proposition 2.5.1
, a von Neumann algebra is the finite linear span of its unitary operators, and then each operator in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
also has the same representation as (5.6). That is, (5.4) holds.

For the uniqueness of the coefficients c
k , just note that for any fixed w 0 in
$$\mathbb{D} - B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
, {ρ
k (w 0)} is an interpolating sequence, see Proposition 5.1.4. Pick such a
$$w_{0} \in \Delta$$
. For each i ≥ 0, there is a bounded holomorphic function g satisfying g(ρ
k (w 0)) = δ
k
i . If there is another sequence
$$\{c_{k}^{{\prime}}\}\in l^{2}$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{Sh(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}^{{\prime}}U_{\rho _{ k}}h(z),\ h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in \Delta,}$$
then
$$\displaystyle{Sg(w_{0}) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}^{{\prime}}g(\rho _{ k}(w_{0}))\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(w_{ 0}) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}g(\rho _{k}(w_{0}))\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(w_{ 0}),}$$
which immediately gives
$$c_{i} = c_{i}^{{\prime}}$$
.
Below we will derive (5.5) to finish the proof of Lemma 5.2.1.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof of (5.5)
FormalPara.Para:
Now write
$$H = L_{a}^{2}(\Delta )$$
and
$$\Lambda = L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
. For each
$$h \in \Lambda$$
, set
$$\displaystyle{e_{h}^{k}(z) = U_{\rho _{ k}}h(z);\,f_{h}^{k}(z) = U_{\rho _{ k}}(Sh)(z),z \in \Delta,\,k = 0,1,\cdots \,.}$$
Clearly e
h
k and f
h
k are in H. Recall that for f 1, f 2 in H, a rank-one operator f 1 ⊗ f 2 on H is defined by
$$\displaystyle{(f_{1} \otimes f_{2})f =\langle f,f_{2}\rangle f_{1},\,f \in H.}$$
By the claim, for any
$$h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
{e
h
k } is a square-summable sequence of H, and hence for any g and h in
$$\Lambda$$
, both
$$\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }e_{g}^{k} \otimes e_{h}^{k}$$
and ∑
k = 0
∞
f
g
k ⊗ f
h
k converge in the operator norm on B(H). Soon we will see that
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }e_{ g}^{k} \otimes e_{ h}^{k} =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }f_{ g}^{k} \otimes f_{ h}^{k}.}$$

In fact, since SM
B = M
B
S, then for any polynomials P and Q
$$\displaystyle{\langle P(B)g,Q(B)h\rangle =\langle P(B)Sg,Q(B)Sh\rangle.}$$
Writing
$$\tilde{g}$$
for Sg and
$$\tilde{h}$$
for Sh, we get
$$\displaystyle{ \int _{\mathbb{D}}\Big((P\overline{Q}) \circ B(w)g(w)\overline{h(w)} - (P\overline{Q}) \circ B(w)\tilde{g}(w)\overline{\tilde{h}(w)}\Big)dA(w) = 0. }$$
Write
$$\Omega \triangleq B(\mathbb{D})$$
, and
$$\Omega = \mathbb{D}$$
. By Theorem 2.1.21
, any continuous function on
$$\overline{\Omega }$$
can be uniformly approximated by functions in the linear span of
$$\displaystyle{\{P\overline{Q}\,:\ P,Q\ \mathrm{are\ polynomials}\}.}$$
Therefore, 5.7
$$\displaystyle{ \int _{\mathbb{D}}v(B(w))\Big(g(w)\overline{h(w)} -\tilde{ g}(w)\overline{\tilde{h}(w)}\Big)dA(w) = 0,\ v \in C(\overline{\Omega }). }$$
Lusin’s Theorem (Theorem 2.1.23
) shows that for each
$$v \in L^{\infty }(\Omega )$$
, there is a uniformly bounded sequence {v
n } in
$$C(\overline{\Omega })$$
such that {v
n } converges in measure to v. Thus by the Dominated Convergence Theorem, (5.7) holds for any
$$v \in L^{\infty }(\Omega )$$
. In particular, for any
$$v \in L^{\infty }(B(\Delta )),$$
(5.7) gives that
$$\displaystyle{\int _{B^{-1}(B(\Delta ))}v(B(w))g(w)\overline{h(w)}dA(w) =\int _{B^{-1}(B(\Delta ))}v(B(w))\tilde{g}(w)\overline{\tilde{h}(w)}dA(w).}$$
Note that
$$B^{-1}(B(\Delta )) =\bigsqcup _{k}\rho _{k}(\Delta )$$
and
$$B\vert _{\rho _{k}(\Delta )}:\rho _{k}(\Delta ) \rightarrow B(\Delta )$$
are biholomorphic. By a simple calculation one can show that for each
$$u \in L^{\infty }(\Delta )$$
,
$$\displaystyle{\int _{\Delta }u(z)\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }(g\overline{h}) \circ \rho _{ k}(z)\vert \rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) =\int _{ \Delta }u(z)\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }(\tilde{g}\overline{\tilde{h}}) \circ \rho _{ k}(z)\vert \rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z).}$$
Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{ \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }(g\overline{h}) \circ \rho _{ k}(z)\vert \rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)\vert ^{2} =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }(\tilde{g}\overline{\tilde{h}}) \circ \rho _{ k}(z)\vert \rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)\vert ^{2},\ \ z \in \Delta. }$$
That is,
$$\displaystyle{\langle \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }(e_{ g}^{k} \otimes e_{ h}^{k})G_{ z},G_{z}\rangle =\langle \sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }(f_{ g}^{k} \otimes f_{ h}^{k})G_{ z},G_{z}\rangle,z \in \Delta,}$$
where G
z is the reproducing kernel of
$$L_{a}^{2}(\Delta )$$
at z. By the property of Berezin transform (see Appendix A), we get 5.8
$$\displaystyle{ \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }e_{ g}^{k} \otimes e_{ h}^{k} =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }f_{ g}^{k} \otimes f_{ h}^{k}. }$$

Next we show the existence of W. For each
$$g \in \Lambda$$
, we set
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} A_{g}: l^{2}& \rightarrow & H {}\\ \{c_{k}\}& \mapsto & \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}e_{g}^{k}, {}\\ \end{array}$$
and
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} B_{g}: l^{2}& \rightarrow & H {}\\ \{c_{k}\}& \mapsto & \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}f_{g}^{k}, {}\\ \end{array}$$
It is easy to check that A
g and B
g are well-defined since both {e
g
k } and {f
g
k } are square-summable sequences from H. Furthermore, we have
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} A_{g}^{{\ast}}: H& \rightarrow & l^{2} {}\\ p& \mapsto & \{\langle p,e_{g}^{k}\rangle \}, {}\\ \end{array}$$
and
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} B_{g}^{{\ast}}: H& \rightarrow & l^{2} {}\\ p& \mapsto & \{\langle p,f_{g}^{k}\rangle \}. {}\\ \end{array}$$
Then for any
$$g,h \in \Lambda$$
,
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} A_{h}A_{g}^{{\ast}}p& =& \sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }\langle p,e_{ g}^{k}\rangle e_{ h}^{k} =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }(e_{ h}^{k} \otimes e_{ g}^{k})p {}\\ & & {}\\ & =& \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }(f_{ h}^{k} \otimes f_{ g}^{k})p = B_{ h}B_{g}^{{\ast}}p,\ p \in H. {}\\ \end{array}$$
The third equality follows from (5.8). So
$$A_{h}A_{g}^{{\ast}} = B_{h}B_{g}^{{\ast}},g,h \in \Lambda.$$
Then it is easy to verify that
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{i=1}^{l}A_{ g_{i}}^{{\ast}}p_{ i}\mapsto \sum _{i=1}^{l}B_{ g_{i}}^{{\ast}}p_{ i},\ p_{i} \in H\,\ \mathrm{and}\ \,g_{i} \in \Lambda }$$
is a well-defined isometry from some subspace of l 2 to another, and by a careful observation, we see that the initial space and the final space are the same. Therefore, this isometry can be extended to a unitary operator from l 2 onto l 2, say U. Specifically, we have
$$\displaystyle{UA_{g}^{{\ast}} = B_{ g}^{{\ast}},\,g \in \Lambda.}$$
Recall that G
w is the reproducing kernel at w of H
$$(w \in \Delta )$$
, and
$$\displaystyle{UA_{g}^{{\ast}}G_{ w} = B_{g}^{{\ast}}G_{ w},\,g \in \Lambda \ \mathrm{and}\ w \in \Delta.}$$
That is, 5.9
$$\displaystyle{ U\{\overline{e_{g}^{k}(w)}\} =\{ \overline{f_{g}^{k}(w)}\}. }$$
Now write the infinite matrix form of U as
$$\displaystyle{(a_{i,j})_{i,j=1}^{\infty },}$$
and put
$$\displaystyle{W = (\overline{a_{i,j}})_{i,j=1}^{\infty }.}$$
Also denote the corresponding operator by W, and clearly W is unitary since U is unitary. Then by (5.9), we get 5.10
$$\displaystyle{ W\{e_{g}^{k}(w)\} =\{ f_{ g}^{k}(w)\},\ g \in \Lambda,w \in \Delta. }$$
This is nothing but (5.5).

The proof of (5.5) is now complete. However, we would like to show something else: (5.10) uniquely determines the operator W. To see this, it suffices to show that for each fixed
$$w_{0} \in \Delta$$
, the span of all {e
g
k (w 0)}
$$(g \in \Lambda )$$
is dense in l 2. Suppose conversely that there is a nonzero vector {d
i } in l 2 such that
$$\langle \{e_{g}^{k}(w_{0})\},\{d_{i}\}\rangle = 0$$
for all
$$g \in \Lambda$$
. That is, 5.11
$$\displaystyle{ \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }\overline{d_{ k}}\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(w_{ 0})g(\rho _{k}(w_{0})) = 0. }$$
On the other hand, for each
$$w_{0} \in \mathbb{D} - B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
,
$$\{\rho _{k}(w_{0})\}$$
is an interpolating sequence. In particular, for each i there is a bounded holomorphic function g satisfying
$$\displaystyle{g(\rho _{k}(w_{0})) =\delta _{ k}^{i},}$$
where δ
k
i denotes theKronecker delta. Kronecker delta That is,
$$\displaystyle{\delta _{k}^{i} = \left \{\begin{array}{ll} 0,&k\neq i, \\ 1,&k = i. \end{array} \right.}$$
By (5.11), we have
$$\overline{d_{i}}\rho _{i}^{{\prime}}(w_{0}) = 0$$
, forcing d
i = 0 (∀i). This is a contradiction. Thus the operator W in (5.5) is unique. □

Section1.Para:
Note that the identity (5.4) holds on V, locally. The notion π
w and matrix W are also locally defined. Below, we will try to get a global version for them.

In Sect. 2.3
in Chap. 2
, we have introduced the definitions of direct continuations and analytic continuation. By convention, throughout this chapter all curves and loops concerned are required to be contained in E, where
$$E = \mathbb{D} - B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
.

If ρ is a local inverse of B and γ is a curve in E such that γ(0) belongs to D(ρ), the definition domain of ρ, then ρ always admits an analytic continuation
$$\tilde{\rho }$$
along γ. By Theorem 2.3.1
, such an analytic continuation is unique, and one can show that this
$$\tilde{\rho }$$
is necessarily a local inverse of B. Then applying the monodromy theorem (Theorem 2.3.4
) shows that each local inverse ρ of B can be extended analytically to any simply connected subdomain of E. Below we will seek a curve L which passes all points in
$$B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
, such that
$$\mathbb{D} - L$$
is simply connected. In this way, one can get a global version of (5.4). The following is from [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: . Then there is a curve L containing

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Let
$$\mathcal{E}$$
be a discrete set in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. Without loss of generality, we assume that
$$\mathcal{E}$$
consists of countably infinitely many points. Since
$$\mathcal{E}$$
is discrete, there is a strictly increasing sequence {r
n } satisfying
$$\displaystyle{\lim _{n\rightarrow \infty }r_{n} = 1\ \mathrm{and}\ \mathcal{E}\subseteq \bigcup r_{n}\mathbb{T}.}$$
Note that each circle
$$r_{n}\mathbb{T}$$
contains only finite points in
$$\mathcal{E}$$
, and then we can draw an infinite polygon L passing along these
$$r_{n}\mathbb{T}$$
and through all points in
$$\mathcal{E}\cap (r_{n}\mathbb{T})$$
.

Since L tends to
$$\mathbb{T}$$
and has no end point on
$$\mathbb{T}$$
,
$$\mathbb{D} - L$$
looks like a snail. See Fig. 5.1, which is provided by Dr. Xie. It is easy to construct a sequence of simply connected open sets U
n whose union is the snail
$$\mathbb{D} - L$$
and
$$\displaystyle{U_{n} \subseteq U_{n+1},\ n = 1,2,\cdots \,.}$$
Therefore,
$$\mathbb{D} - L$$
is simply connected. □
