Section1.Para:
In the proof Lemma 5.2.3, one sees that the curve L consists of at most countably many arcs and L is relatively closed in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. Here, by an arc we mean a subset in
$$\mathbb{C}$$
which is C 1-homeomorphic to some segment.

By Proposition 5.1.1 and Lemma 5.2.3, there is a curve L containing
$$B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
such that
$$\mathbb{D} - L$$
is simply connected. Note that all ρ
k are local inverse of B, and by the monodromy theorem all ρ
k are holomorphic in
$$\mathbb{D} - L$$
. For each w in
$$\mathbb{D} - L$$
, define
$$\displaystyle{\pi _{w}(h) =\{ h \circ \rho _{k}(w)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(w)\},\,h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}).}$$
By the claim below Lemma 5.2.2,
$$\pi _{w}(h) \in l^{2}$$
. Furthermore, Guo and Huang [GH4] obtained the following.

FormalPara.Heading: Theorem 5.2.4
FormalPara.Para:
Suppose B is a thin Blaschke product. If S is a unitary operator on the Bergman space which commutes with M B , then there is a unique operator W: l 2 → l 2 such that
5.12
$$\displaystyle{ W\pi _{w}(h) =\pi _{w}(Sh),\ h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\ w \in \mathbb{D} - L. }$$
This W is necessarily a unitary operator. Thus, there is a unique vector {c k } in l 2 satisfying
5.13
$$\displaystyle{ Sh(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z),\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in \mathbb{D} - L. }$$
where all holomorphic functions ρ k satisfy
$$B \circ \rho _{k}\vert _{\mathbb{D}-L} = B$$
, and the right side of (5.13) converges uniformly on compact subsets of
$$\mathbb{D} - L.$$

Section1.Para:
The operator W is exactly the one that appeared in the proof of Lemma 5.2.2. If S is any operator in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
, then both (5.12) and (5.13) still hold. In this case, W is not necessarily unitary.

In fact, for a finite Blaschke product B, such an operator W in (5.12) was also obtained by Douglas, Sun and Zheng in [DSZ]. Motivated by a result in [DSZ], we can show that W has a very restricted form. To see this, let V be chosen as in Lemma 5.2.1 and put
$$\mathcal{E} = B^{-1}(\mathcal{E}_{B})$$
in Lemma 5.2.3. Since V can be shrunk such that
$$\overline{\rho _{i}(V )} \cap \overline{\rho _{j}(V )}$$
are empty whenever i ≠ j, we may carefully choose a curve L with all L ∩ρ
i (V ) being empty.

Note that each ρ
k maps ρ
j (V ) biholomorphically onto some ρ
i (V ), and hence ρ
k ∘ρ
j | V makes sense; locally ρ
k ∘ρ
j equals ρ
i . Now consider the (n + 1)-th row of both sides of (5.12). Let {d
k } ∈ l 2 be the (n + 1)-th row of W, then by (5.12), 5.14
$$\displaystyle{ Sh(\rho _{n}(w))\rho _{n}^{{\prime}}(w) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }d_{ k}h(\rho _{k}(w))\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(w),\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})\ \mathrm{and}\ w \in V. }$$
By the above discussion, there is a permutation π
n such that 5.15
$$\displaystyle{ \rho _{k} \circ \rho _{n}\vert _{V } =\rho _{\pi _{n}(k)}\vert _{V },k = 1,2,\cdots \,, }$$
and hence 5.16
$$\displaystyle{ \rho _{k}^{{\prime}}\circ \rho _{ n}\rho _{n}^{{\prime}}\vert _{ V } =\rho _{ \pi _{n}(k)}^{{\prime}}\vert _{ V }. }$$

Combining (5.14), (5.15) with (5.16) shows that for each
$$h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
,
$$\displaystyle{Sh(\rho _{n}(w))\rho _{n}^{{\prime}}(w) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }d_{\pi _{ n}(k)}h(\rho _{k} \circ \rho _{n}(w))\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}\circ \rho _{ n}(w)\rho _{n}^{{\prime}}(w),\ w \in V.}$$
Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{Sh(\rho _{n}(w)) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }d_{\pi _{ n}(k)}h(\rho _{k} \circ \rho _{n}(w))\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}\circ \rho _{ n}(w),\ w \in V,}$$
and hence
$$\displaystyle{Sh(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }d_{\pi _{ n}(k)}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z),\,z \in \mathbb{D} - L.}$$
Therefore by (5.13)
$$\displaystyle{ \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }d_{\pi _{ n}(k)}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z),\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in \mathbb{D} - L. }$$
By uniqueness of the coefficients, we get
$$\displaystyle{d_{\pi _{n}(k)} = c_{k},k = 1,2,\cdots \,.}$$
Put
$$\sigma _{n} =\pi _{ n}^{-1}(n \geq 1)$$
, and then
$$d_{k} = c_{\sigma _{n}(k)},k = 1,2,\cdots \,.$$
Therefore, the form of W is presented as follows, see [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: The infinite unitary matrix W in Theorem
has a very restricted form. Precisely, there is a unit vector {c

Equation.EquationSource: $$\displaystyle{W = \left (\begin{array}{ccccc} c_{1} & c_{2} & \cdots & c_{n} &\cdots \\ c_{ \sigma _{1}(1)} & c_{\sigma _{1}(2)} & \cdots & c_{\sigma _{1}(n)} & \cdots \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots & \vdots\\ c_{ \sigma _{m}(1)} & c_{\sigma _{m}(2)} & \cdots &c_{\sigma _{m}(n)} & \cdots \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots & \ddots\\ \end{array} \right ).}$$

Section1.Para:
Below, we will use Theorem 5.2.4 to give a geometric characterization for when
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial. First, we need the following result from [GH4]. In the case of B being a finite Blaschke product, it is given by Douglas et al. [DSZ, Lemma 5.1.].

Para.Emphasis: , suppose S is an operator in

Equation.EquationSource: $$\displaystyle{ Sh(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z),\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in \mathbb{D} - L, }$$

Section1.Para: Recall that for each local inverse ρ of B, [ρ] denotes the equivalent class of all analytic continuation σ of ρ such that D(σ) ⊆ E.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Suppose S is an operator in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
given by
$$\displaystyle{Sh(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z),\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in \mathbb{D} - L,}$$
where {c
k } ∈ l 2. Since {c
k } is in l 2, to prove Lemma 5.2.6 it is enough to show that if ρ j and
$$\rho _{j^{{\prime}}}$$
are equivalent, i.e.
$$[\rho _{j}] = [\rho _{j^{{\prime}}}]$$
, then
$$c_{j} = c_{j^{{\prime}}}.$$
To see this, fix a point z 0 in
$$\mathbb{D} - L$$
and assume that ρ
j and
$$\rho _{j^{{\prime}}}$$
are equivalent. Then there is a loop γ in E based at z 0 such that
$$\rho _{j^{{\prime}}}$$
is the analytic continuation of ρ
j along γ. By (5.4), for each
$$f \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
, the sum
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}f \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)}$$
makes sense for each z ∈ γ and it is locally holomorphic. As done in the proof of [DSZ, Lemma 5.1.], suppose along the loop γ each ρ in
$$\{\rho _{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty }$$
is extended analytically to a holomorphic function denoted by
$$\hat{\rho }$$
, defined on some neighborhood of z 0. Then we have 5.17
$$\displaystyle{ \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}f \circ \rho _{k}(z_{0})\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z_{ 0}) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}f \circ \widehat{\rho _{k}}(z_{0})\widehat{\rho _{k}}^{{\prime}}(z_{ 0}). }$$
Since
$$\{\rho _{k}(z_{0})\}$$
is an interpolating sequence, there exists a bounded holomorphic function f over
$$\mathbb{D}$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{f(\rho _{j^{{\prime}}}(z_{0})) = 1\quad \mathrm{and}\quad f(\rho _{k}(z_{0})) = 0,\ k\neq j^{{\prime}}.}$$
Since
$$\rho _{j^{{\prime}}} =\widehat{\rho _{j}}$$
, then by (5.17)
$$c_{j} = c_{j^{{\prime}}}.$$
□

Section1.Para:
Denote by D(f) the domain of definition for any function f. Now define G[ρ] to be the union of all graphs G(σ) of members σ in the equivalent class [ρ] of ρ, with D(σ) ⊆ E; that is,
$$\displaystyle{G[\rho ] =\bigcup _{\sigma \in [\rho ]}\{(z,\sigma (z)): z \in D(\sigma ) \subseteq E\}.}$$

Clearly, G[ρ] is a subset of E × E. In fact, G[ρ] is a connected Riemann surface since it contains only points which locally can be written as (z, σ(z)), where σ are some local inverses defined on a neighborhood of some z 0 ∈ E. Also, observe that for any local inverses ρ and σ of B, G[ρ] = G[σ] if and only if [ρ] = [σ]; and either G[ρ] = G[σ] or G[ρ] ∩ G[σ] = ∅. Following [DSZ] and [GSZZ], define
$$\displaystyle{S_{B} \triangleq \{ (z,w) \in \mathbb{D}^{2};z \in E\,\mathrm{and}\,B(z) = B(w)\},}$$
equipped with the topology inherited from the natural topology of
$$\mathbb{D}^{2}.$$
It is not difficult to see that S
B
is a Riemann surface whose components are G[ρ], where ρ are local inverses of B. The Riemann surface
$$\displaystyle{G[z] =\{ (z,z): z \in E\}}$$
is called the identity component, or the trivial component of S
B . identity component of S
B
trivial component of S
B

Define π 1 and π 2 by setting
$$\displaystyle{\pi _{1}(z,w) = z,}$$
and
$$\displaystyle{\pi _{2}(z,w) = w}$$
for all
$$(z,w) \in \mathbb{C}^{2}$$
. Rewrite π
ρ for the restriction π 1: G[ρ] → E. By the discussion above Lemma 5.2.3, for any local inverse ρ of B and any curve γ ∈ E, there must exist a unique analytic continuation
$$\tilde{\rho }$$
of ρ along γ. This implies that π
ρ is onto. Then for each z ∈ E, one can put
$$\displaystyle{[\rho ](z) =\{ w: (z,w) \in G[\rho ]\},}$$
which is nonempty. Furthermore, by using Lemma 5.2.1 one can show the following [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: For each local inverse ρ of B, π
: G[ρ] → E is a covering map.

Section1.Para:
A standard result in topology says that for a covering map p: Y → X with X arc-connected, the number ♯ p −1(x) does not depend on the choice of x ∈ X, called the multiplicity of p, or the number of sheets of p. Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{\sharp (\pi _{\rho })^{-1}(z) = \sharp [\rho ](z)}$$
is either a constant integer or ∞, called the multiplicity of G[ρ], or the number of sheets
multiplicity of G[ρ] of G[ρ]. For simplicity, we rewrite ♯[ρ] for ♯[ρ](z) to emphasize that it does not depend on z. If ♯[ρ] < ∞, then the component G[ρ] is called finite; otherwise, G[ρ] is called infinite.
Combining Theorem 5.2.4, Lemma 5.2.6 with Proposition 5.2.7 yields the following, due to Guo and Huang [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: For a thin Blaschke product B, if there is no nontrivial component G[ρ] of S

Section1.Para:
The existence of thin Blaschke products with the above property will be carried out in Sect. 5.4 of Chap. 5
. Also, the sufficient condition in Proposition 5.2.8 is also necessary for
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
to be trivial, as will be seen in Sect. 5.5 in Chap. 5
.

FormalPara.Heading: Remark 5.2.9
FormalPara.Para:
All definitions appearing in this section, such as local inverse, analytic continuation, can also be carried to the case of finite Blaschke products ϕ. However, since
$$\sharp \phi ^{-1}(\phi (z)) =\mathrm{ order}\,\phi <\infty$$
for each z ∈ E, any component G[ρ] of S
ϕ must have finite multiplicity where ρ is a local inverse of ϕ [GH4].

Section1.Heading:
Geometric Characterization for
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
Section1.Para:
Last section presents the form of operators in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
where B is a thin Blaschke product. Based on this, this section will provide a complete geometric characterization for the nontriviality of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
.
The following, due to Guo and Huang [GH4], is the main result of this section. Its proof will be placed at the end of this section.

Para.Emphasis: Suppose B is a thin Blaschke product. Then
is nontrivial if and only if the Riemann surface S
has a nontrivial component with finite multiplicity.

Section1.Para:
Some notations are in order. For any local inverse ρ of B, the inverse map ρ −1 of ρ is also a local inverse of B, and we rewrite ρ − for ρ −1. For any subset F of E × E, write
$$F^{-} =\{ (w,z): (z,w) \in F\}.$$
Thus,
$$\displaystyle{G^{-}[\rho ] =\{ (w,z): (z,w) \in G[\rho ]\}.}$$
In [GH4], a geometric characterization for G[ρ −] was obtained as follows.

Para.Emphasis: For each local inverse ρ, we have

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Suppose z 0 ∈ D(ρ). Clearly,
$$\rho ^{-}\big(\rho (z_{0})\big) = z_{0}.$$
Let z ∈ E, and γ be any curve that connects z 0 with z. Denote by
$$\tilde{\rho }$$
the analytic continuation of ρ along γ, and then
$$\tilde{\rho }(\gamma )$$
is a curve connecting ρ(z 0) and
$$\tilde{\rho }(z)$$
. Let
$$\widetilde{\rho ^{-}}$$
be the analytic continuation of ρ − along
$$\tilde{\rho }(\gamma )$$
. Since
$$\rho ^{-}\big(\rho (z_{0})\big) = z_{0},$$
then
$$\displaystyle{\widetilde{\rho ^{-}}(\tilde{\rho }) = id}$$
holds on the curve γ. In particular,
$$\widetilde{\rho ^{-}}\big(\tilde{\rho }(z)\big) = z$$
, forcing
$$\displaystyle{(\tilde{\rho }(z),z) \in G[\widetilde{\rho ^{-}}] = G[\rho ^{-}].}$$
The above means that
$$\displaystyle{G^{-}[\rho ] \subseteq G[\rho ^{-}].}$$
Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{\{G^{-}[\rho ]\}^{-}\subseteq G^{-}[\rho ^{-}] \subseteq G[\{\rho ^{-}\}^{-}],}$$
Clearly,
$$\displaystyle{G[\rho ] \subseteq G^{-}[\rho ^{-}] \subseteq G[\rho ],}$$
forcing
$$G^{-}[\rho ^{-}] = G[\rho ]$$
, and hence
$$G[\rho ^{-}] = G^{-}[\rho ]$$
. □

Section1.Para:
Since π 1: G[ρ −] → E is a covering map, by Proposition 5.3.2 π 2: G[ρ] → E, (z, w) → w is also a covering map, and the multiplicity ♯[ρ −] of
$$\pi _{1}\vert _{G[\rho ^{-}]}$$
equals that of π 2 | G[ρ]. If both ♯[ρ] and ♯[ρ −] are finite, then we say that the component G[ρ] of S
B is bi-finite. Later, it turns out that G[ρ] is bi-finite if and only if it is finite, see Proposition 5.3.4. Note that S
B has a nontrivial bi-finite component if and only if there exists a nontrivial local inverse ρ of B, such that one of the covering maps π
ρ : G[ρ] → E and π 2: G[ρ] → E has finite multiplicity.

Before continuing, we need some preparations. If ♯[ρ] = n < ∞, then π 1: G[ρ] → E is a covering map of finite sheets. Then for each z ∈ E, there is a small disk
$$\Delta (z \in \Delta )$$
and n local inverse ρ
i (1 ≤ i ≤ n) defined on
$$\Delta$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{\pi _{1}\vert _{G[\rho ]}^{-1}(\Delta ) =\bigsqcup _{ i=1}^{n}\{(w,\rho _{ i}(w)): w \in \Delta \}.}$$
In this case, define 5.18
$$\displaystyle{ \sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ]}h \circ \sigma (w)\,\sigma ^{{\prime}}(w) \triangleq \sum _{ i=1}^{n}h \circ \rho _{ i}(w)\,\rho _{i}^{{\prime}}(w),w \in \Delta, }$$
where h is any function over E or
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. Then we get a linear map
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
defined by
$$\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}h(z) \equiv \sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ]}h \circ \sigma (z)\,\sigma ^{{\prime}}(z),\,z \in E.}$$
One can verify that the map
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
is well-defined; that is, the value
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}h(z)$$
does not depend on the choice of disks
$$\Delta$$
which contains z. The functions h over E or
$$\mathbb{D}$$
are not necessarily holomorphic. Sometimes we write
$$\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}h =\sum _{\rho _{i}\in [\rho ]}h \circ \rho _{i}\rho _{i}^{{\prime}}}$$
to emphasize that this
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
maps holomorphic functions to holomorphic functions. In particular, the trivial component [z] gives the identity operator I, i.e.
$$\mathcal{E}_{[z]} = I$$
. It is worthwhile to mention that those operators
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
were first considered in [DSZ]. Similar as (5.18), define
$$\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}_{[\vert \rho \vert ]}h(z) =\sum _{\rho _{i}\in [\rho ]}h \circ \rho _{i}(z)\vert \rho _{i}^{{\prime}}(z)\vert.}$$

It is well-known that a square-summable holomorphic function on a punctured disk can always be extended analytically to the whole disk. Since
$$\mathbb{D} - E$$
is discrete in
$$\mathbb{D},$$
then each function f in L
a
2(E) can be extended analytically to the unit disk
$$\mathbb{D}$$
; that is, f can be regarded as a member in
$$L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
. Thus, it is reasonable to write
$$\displaystyle{L_{a}^{2}(E) = L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}).}$$

As mentioned above,
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
maps holomorphic functions to holomorphic functions. Soon we will see that
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
defines a linear map from
$$L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
to L
a
2(E). Furthermore,
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}: L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}) \rightarrow L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
is a bounded operator, see as follows [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: If G[ρ] is a bi-finite component of S

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Assume that G[ρ] is a bi-finite component of S
B . First we will show that
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
is bounded. To see this, let h ∈ C
c (E); that is, h is a compactly supported continuous function over E. For each open set U that admits a complete local inverse
$$\{\rho _{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty }$$
, we have 5.19
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} \int _{U}\vert \mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}h(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z)& \leq & C\int _{ U}\sum _{\rho _{i}\in [\rho ]}\vert h \circ \rho _{i}(z)\vert ^{2}\vert \rho _{ i}^{{\prime}}(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) \\ & =& C\sum _{\rho _{i}\in [\rho ]}\int _{\rho _{i}(U)}\vert h(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z), {}\end{array}$$
where C is a numerical constant that depends only on ♯[ρ].

Since E is an open set which can be covered by open disks with each admitting a complete local inverse, E can be written as the union of countably many of them. The reasoning is as follows. For each z ∈ E, there is an r = r(z) > 0 such that the disk O(z, r(z)) admits a complete local inverse. Then by Proposition 3.2.1
, one can pick countable disks O(z, r(z)) whose union equals E.

Now assume that {U
j } is such a covering of E and each U
j admits a complete local inverse
$$\{\rho _{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty }$$
. We emphasize that the family
$$\{\rho _{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty }$$
is fixed once their common definition domain U
j is fixed. Set
$$\displaystyle{E_{1} = U_{1}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad E_{j} = U_{j} -\bigcup _{1\leq i<j}U_{i}\,(j \geq 2).}$$
As (5.19), we also have
$$\displaystyle{\int _{E_{j}}\Big\vert \mathcal{E}_{[\vert \rho \vert ]}\vert h\vert (z)\Big\vert ^{2}dA(z) \leq C\sum _{\rho _{ i}\in [\rho ]}\int _{\rho _{i}(E_{j})}\vert h(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) \equiv C\sum _{\rho _{ i}\in [\rho ]}\mu (\rho _{i}(E_{j})),}$$
where μ is a measure defined by
$$\displaystyle{\mu (F) =\int _{F}\vert h(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z)}$$
for each Lebesgue measurable subset F of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. Since
$$E = \cup U_{j} = \sqcup E_{j}$$
, then 5.20
$$\displaystyle{ \int _{E}\vert \mathcal{E}_{[\vert \rho \vert ]}\vert h\vert (z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) \leq C\sum _{ j=1}^{\infty }\sum _{ \rho _{i}\in [\rho ]}\mu (\rho _{i}(E_{j})). }$$
Write
$$m = \sharp [\rho ^{-}] <\infty.$$
Let us recall a fact in measure theory: for measurable sets F and F
j , if ∪ j = 1
k
F
j ⊆ F, and for each point z ∈ F, there are at most m sets F
j containing z, then
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{j=1}^{k}\chi _{ F_{j}} \leq m\chi _{F},}$$
and hence
$$\sum _{j=1}^{k}\mu (F_{j}) \leq m\mu (F).$$
Below, we will apply this result. By our choice of E
j (E
j ⊆ U
j ) and Proposition 5.3.2, it follows from that for any w ∈ E, there are at most m sets E
j such that w ∈ ρ
i (E
j ) for some ρ
i ∈ [ρ]. Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{\rho _{i}\in [\rho ]}\sum _{j=1}^{k}\mu (\rho _{ i}(E_{j})) \leq m\mu (E).}$$
Letting k tends to infinity shows that
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{\rho _{i}\in [\rho ]}\sum _{j=1}^{\infty }\mu (\rho _{ i}(E_{j})) \leq m\mu (E);}$$
and thus by (5.20)
$$\displaystyle{\int _{\mathbb{D}}\Big\vert \mathcal{E}_{[\vert \rho \vert ]}\vert h\vert (z)\Big\vert ^{2}dA(z) \leq mC\|h\|^{2}.}$$
By a limit argument, it is easy to see that the above identity also holds for each
$$h \in C(\mathbb{D})$$
, which immediately gives that
$$\displaystyle{\int _{\mathbb{D}}\vert \mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}f(z)\vert ^{2}dA(z) \leq \int _{ \mathbb{D}}\Big\vert \mathcal{E}_{[\vert \rho \vert ]}\vert f\vert (z)\Big\vert ^{2}dA(z) \leq mC\|f\|^{2},f \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}).}$$
That is,
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}: L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}) \rightarrow L_{a}^{2}(E)$$
is a bounded operator. By the comments above Lemma 5.3.3,
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
can be regarded as a bounded operator from
$$L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
to
$$L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
.

Also,
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ^{-}]}$$
is a bounded operator from
$$L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
to
$$L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
. Below we will show that
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}^{{\ast}} = \mathcal{E}_{[\rho ^{-}]}.$$

To see this, let U be a fixed open subset of E admitting a complete local inverse, h be a bounded measurable function whose support is contained in
$$\rho _{i_{0}}(U)$$
for some i 0, and g ∈ C
c (E). Since
$$m = \sharp [\rho ^{-}]$$
, we may write 5.21
$$\displaystyle{ [\rho ^{-}]\rho _{ i_{0}}(U) =\bigsqcup _{ j=1}^{m}\check{\rho _{ j}}(U), }$$
where
$$\check{\rho _{j}}$$
are local inverses of B on U. That is, on
$$\rho _{i_{0}}(U)$$
there are m members
$$\rho _{k_{j}}(1 \leq j \leq m)$$
in [ρ −], and there are m integers
$$k_{j}^{{\prime}}(1 \leq j \leq m)$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{\rho _{k_{j}} \circ \rho _{i_{0}}(z) =\rho _{k_{j}^{{\prime}}}(z),\,z \in U.}$$
Rewrite
$$\check{\rho _{j}}$$
for
$$\rho _{k_{j}^{{\prime}}}(1 \leq j \leq m)$$
, and then we have (5.21).

Then for each j(1 ≤ j ≤ m), there is a local inverse
$$\sigma _{j}:\check{\rho _{j}}(U) \rightarrow \rho _{i_{0}}(U)$$
and σ
j is onto. Since σ
j ∈ [ρ] and h is supported on
$$\rho _{i_{0}}(U)$$
, we have
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} \int _{\check{\rho _{j}}(U)}\sum _{\rho _{k}\in [\rho ]}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)\overline{g(z)}dA(z)& =& \int _{\check{\rho _{ j}}(U)}h \circ \sigma _{j}(z)\sigma _{j}^{{\prime}}(z)\overline{g(z)}dA(z) {}\\ & =& \int _{\rho _{i_{ 0}}(U)}h \circ \sigma _{j}(\sigma _{j}^{-}(w)) {}\\ & & \sigma _{j}^{{\prime}}(\sigma _{ j}^{-}(w))\vert \sigma _{ j}^{-^{{\prime}} }(w)\vert ^{2}\overline{g(\sigma _{ j}^{-}(w))}dA(w) {}\\ & =& \int _{\rho _{i_{ 0}}(U)}h(w)\overline{g(\sigma _{j}^{-}(w))\sigma _{j}^{-^{{\prime}} }(w)}dA(w). {}\\ \end{array}$$
That is,
$$\displaystyle{\int _{\check{\rho _{j}}(U)}\sum _{\rho _{k}\in [\rho ]}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)\overline{g(z)}dA(z) =\int _{\rho _{ i_{0}}(U)}h(w)\overline{g(\sigma _{j}^{-}(w))\sigma _{ j}^{-^{{\prime}} }(w)}dA(w).}$$
Since h is supported in
$$\rho _{i_{0}}(U)$$
, by (5.21) one can verify that
$$\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}h =\sum _{\rho _{i}\in [\rho ]}\sum _{j=1}^{m}\chi _{ \check{\rho _{j}}(U)}h \circ \rho _{i}\,\rho _{i}^{{\prime}},}$$
and hence
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} \langle \mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}h,g\rangle & =& \sum _{j=1}^{m}\int _{ \check{\rho _{j}}(U)}\sum _{\rho _{i}\in [\rho ]}h \circ \rho _{i}(z)\rho _{i}^{{\prime}}(z)\overline{g(z)}dA(z) {}\\ & =& \sum _{j=1}^{m}\int _{ \rho _{i_{0}}(U)}h(w)\overline{g(\sigma _{j}^{-}(w))\sigma _{ j}^{-^{{\prime}} }(w)}dA(w). {}\\ & =& \int _{\mathbb{D}}h(w)\chi _{\rho _{i_{ 0}}(U)}\overline{\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ^{-}]}g(\sigma (w))\sigma ^{{\prime}}(w)}dA(w) {}\\ & =& \langle h,\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ^{-}]}g\rangle. {}\\ \end{array}$$
That is,
$$\displaystyle{\langle \mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}h,g\rangle =\langle h,\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ^{-}]}g\rangle.}$$
Since each compact subset of E is contained in the union of finite open sets like
$$\rho _{i_{0}}(U)$$
, the above identity also holds for any h ∈ C
c (E). Then by a limit argument, the above holds for any
$$g,h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
. Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}^{{\ast}} = \mathcal{E}_{ [\rho ^{-}]}.}$$
Besides, since both
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ^{-}]}$$
and
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
commute with M
B ,
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]} \in \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
. The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para: Below, we need a property of finite Blaschke products, as mentioned in [DSZ] and implied in [DPW], but without proof. This property is also shared by thin Blaschke products.

Para.Emphasis: For a finite or thin Blaschke product B, let ρ be one of its local inverse. Then

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
First, assume that B is a finite Blaschke product. Let us have a sketch of the geometric analysis of B, see the paragraph below Corollary 4.2.4
. For a fixed point
$$w_{0} \in \mathbb{T}$$
, B −1(B(w 0)) consists of exactly n different points (in anti-clockwise direction)
$$\displaystyle{w_{0},\cdots \,,w_{n-1},}$$
which lie on
$$\mathbb{T}$$
. For each j(0 ≤ j ≤ n − 1), there is a unique local inverse ρ
j of B defined on a neighborhood of w 0 such that
$$\displaystyle{\rho _{j}(w_{0}) = w_{j},}$$
and all ρ
j extend analytically to a neighborhood
$$\Omega$$
of
$$\mathbb{T}$$
. Let
$$\widehat{w_{0}} \in \mathbb{D}$$
be enough close to w 0, and then
$$B^{-1}(B(\widehat{w_{0}}))$$
consists of exactly n different points
$$\widehat{w_{0}},\cdots \,,\widehat{w_{n-1}},$$
in anti-clockwise direction. Furthermore, we have
$$\rho _{j} \circ \rho _{k} =\rho _{k} \circ \rho _{j}$$
on
$$\Omega$$
.

Below, we will derive a simple formula for ♯[ρ]. For simplicity, we define the sequence
$$\{\widehat{w_{n}}\}$$
to be
$$\displaystyle{\widehat{w_{0}},\cdots \,,\widehat{w_{n-1}},\widehat{w_{0}},\cdots \,,\widehat{w_{n-1}},\cdots \,.}$$

Then those ρ
j satisfies
$$\displaystyle{\rho _{j}(\widehat{w_{i}}) =\widehat{ w_{i+j}},0 \leq i \leq n - 1.}$$
Since
$$[(\widehat{w_{0}},\widehat{w_{j}})] = [(\widehat{w_{i}},\widehat{w_{i+j}})],$$
for any ρ ∈ {ρ
j } we get
$$\displaystyle{\sharp [\rho ] = \frac{\sharp \{(w,z) \in G[\rho ]: w =\widehat{ w_{0}},\cdots \,,\widehat{w_{n-1}}\}} {n}.}$$
Note that
$$\displaystyle{\sharp \{(w,z) \in G[\rho ]: w =\widehat{ w_{0}},\cdots \,,\widehat{w_{n-1}}\} = \sharp \{(w,z) \in G[\rho ]: z =\widehat{ w_{0}},\cdots \,,\widehat{w_{n-1}}\},}$$
and by Proposition 5.3.2 we get
$$\sharp [\rho ] = \sharp [\rho ^{-}]$$
.

Now assume that B is a thin Blaschke product and [ρ] is one component of S
B . As we will see, B restricted on an appropriate domain
$$\Omega _{t} \subseteq \mathbb{D}$$
behaves like a finite Blaschke product, and local inverses ρ ∗ of
$$B\vert _{\Omega _{t}}$$
are well-defined. In fact, let r be any fixed number in (0, 1) and put
$$\displaystyle{t^{{\prime}} =\max \{ \vert B(z)\vert: \vert z\vert \leq r\}.}$$
By Proposition 5.1.1, {B(z): z ∈ Z(B
′ )} is a discrete subset of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, and then we may take a number t such that
$$\displaystyle{t\not\in \{\vert B(z)\vert: z \in Z(B^{{\prime}})\}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad t^{{\prime}} <t <1.}$$
Let
$$\Omega _{t}$$
denote the component of {z: | B(z) | < t} containing
$$r\mathbb{D}$$
. By the maximum modulus principle, it is not difficult to see that
$$\Omega _{t}$$
is a simply-connected domain; and by the choice of t, the boundary of
$$\Omega _{t}$$
is analytic, and hence a Jordan curve. Then by Riemann’s mapping theorem, there is a biholomorphic map
$$f: \mathbb{D} \rightarrow \Omega _{t}$$
, which extends to a homeomorphism from
$$\overline{\mathbb{D}}$$
onto
$$\overline{\Omega _{t}}$$
. By Lemma 5.1.2,
$$B\vert _{\Omega _{t}}: \Omega _{t} \rightarrow t\mathbb{D}$$
is a proper map, and then
$$B \circ f: \mathbb{D} \rightarrow t\mathbb{D}$$
is also a proper map. By Theorem 2.1.3
, there is a finite Blaschke product B 0 such that B ∘ f = tB 0.

This observation shows that if ♯[ρ] < ∞, then by choosing enough large
$$\Omega _{t}$$
we get
$$\sharp [\rho ^{{\ast}}] = \sharp [\rho ]$$
. Then by the above result for finite Blashcke products,
$$\displaystyle{\sharp [\rho ^{-}] \geq \sharp [\rho ^{-{\ast}}] = \sharp [\rho ^{{\ast}}] = \sharp [\rho ].}$$
If ♯[ρ] = ∞, then the above reasoning shows that for any integer k, ♯[ρ −] ≥ k, and hence
$$\sharp [\rho ^{-}] \geq \sharp [\rho ].$$
Therefore, in either case
$$\sharp [\rho ^{-}] \geq \sharp [\rho ]$$
, and similarly
$$\sharp [\rho ] \geq \sharp [\rho ^{-}]$$
, forcing
$$\sharp [\rho ] = \sharp [\rho ^{-}]$$
. The proof of Proposition 5.3.4 is complete. □

FormalPara.Heading: Proof of Theorem 5.3.1
FormalPara.Para:
Suppose B is a thin Blaschke product. It suffices to show that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is nontrivial if and only if there is a nontrivial local inverse ρ such that ♯[ρ] < ∞. First we deal with the “if” part. If there is a nontrivial local inverse ρ such that ♯[ρ] < ∞, then by Proposition 5.3.4
$$\displaystyle{\sharp [\rho ^{-}] = \sharp [\rho ] <\infty,}$$
which, combined with Lemma 5.3.3, shows that
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]} \in \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B).$$
By the local representation of
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
, we have
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}\neq cI$$
for any constant c since ρ ≠ id. Therefore,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is nontrivial.
The converse direction follows directly from Proposition 5.2.8. The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para:
It is natural to ask for which thin Blaschke product B, M
B has a nontrivial reducing subspace. The following provides such an example.

FormalPara.Heading: Example 5.3.5
FormalPara.Para:
Write ϕ = h ∘φ, where
$$h \in H^{\infty }(\mathbb{D})$$
and φ is a finite Blaschke product with
$$\mathrm{order}\,\,\varphi \geq 2.$$
Then we have
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi ) \supseteq \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\varphi )$$
. Since
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\varphi )$$
is nontrivial [HSXY], then
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi )$$
is nontrivial. For example, Proposition 2.1.11
shows that for each thin Blaschke product B, B ∘φ is still a thin Blaschke product, and M
B∘φ has nontrivial reducing subspaces.

Section1.Para:
For a thin Blaschke product B, if there is a member ρ in
$$\mathrm{Aut}(\mathbb{D})(\rho \neq id)$$
satisfying B ∘ρ = B, then
$$\displaystyle{U_{\rho }: f \rightarrow f \circ \rho \ \rho ^{{\prime}},\,f \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})}$$
defines a unitary operator in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
, and thus
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is nontrivial. However, such a B is strongly restricted. This is characterized by the following, which is of independent interest, see [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: Given a thin Blaschke product B, if there is a member ρ in
(ρ ≠ id) satisfying B ∘ρ = B, then there exists a thin Blaschke product B
, an integer n(n ≥ 2) and a point

Section1.Para:
The finite-Blaschke-product version of the above first appeared in [DSZ, Lemma 8.1]. Proposition 5.3.6 is sharp in the sense that it fails for interpolating Blaschke products, especially for those holomorphic covering maps
$$B: \mathbb{D} \rightarrow \mathbb{D} - F$$
, with F a discrete subset of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, see Example 6.3.9
in Chap. 6

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para: The proof is from [GH4].

Assume that B is a thin Blaschke product, and there is a member ρ in
$$\mathrm{Aut}(\mathbb{D})(\rho \neq id)$$
satisfying B ∘ρ = B. Without loss of generality, we may assume that B has only simple zeros; otherwise we shall replace B with φ
w ∘ B, and Proposition 5.1.4(2) shows that φ
w ∘ B is also a thin Blaschke product. First, we will show that the group G generated by ρ is finite. To see this, assume conversely that G is not finite. Under this assumption, we first show that there is a z 0 ∈ Z(B) such that for all
$$i,j \in \mathbb{Z}$$
with i ≠ j, 5.22
$$\displaystyle{ \rho ^{i}(z_{ 0})\neq \rho ^{j}(z_{ 0}), }$$
where ρ
j denotes the j-th iterate of ρ. If (5.22) were not true, then there would be a positive integer n 1 satisfying
$$\displaystyle{\rho ^{n_{1} }(z_{0}) = z_{0}.}$$
Now take some z 1 ∈ Z(B) such that z 1 ≠ z 0. If {ρ
j (z 1)} are pairwise different, then we are done; otherwise, there would be a positive integer n 2 satisfying
$$\displaystyle{\rho ^{n_{2} }(z_{1}) = z_{1}.}$$
Clearly,
$$\rho ^{n_{1}n_{2}}$$
is a member in
$$\mathrm{Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
satisfying
$$\displaystyle{\rho ^{n_{1}n_{2} }(z_{0}) = z_{0}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \rho ^{n_{1}n_{2} }(z_{1}) = z_{1}.}$$
That is,
$$\rho ^{n_{1}n_{2}}$$
has two different fixed points z 0 and z 1 in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. However, by Milnor [Mi, Theorem 1.12] each member in
$$\mathrm{Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
admitting at least two different fixed points must be the identity map, and hence
$$\rho ^{n_{1}n_{2}} = id$$
. This is a contradiction. Therefore, there exists some z 0 ∈ Z(B) such that
$$\{\rho ^{j}(z_{0})\}$$
are pairwise different, as desired.

Thus, if G were not infinite, then
$$\{\rho ^{j}(z_{0})\}_{j\in \mathbb{Z}}$$
were a subsequence in Z(B), and hence a thin Blaschke sequence. Thus we would have
$$\displaystyle{\lim _{j\rightarrow \infty }\prod _{k\in \mathbb{Z},k\neq j}d(\rho ^{j}(z_{ 0}),\rho ^{k}(z_{ 0})) = 1.}$$
However, since the hyperbolic metric d is invariant under Mobius maps,
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{k\in \mathbb{Z},k\neq j}d(\rho ^{j}(z_{ 0}),\rho ^{k}(z_{ 0})) \equiv \prod _{k\in \mathbb{Z}-\{0\}}d(z_{0},\rho ^{k}(z_{ 0})) <1,\quad j \in \mathbb{Z}.}$$
This is a contradiction. Therefore, G is finite.

By the theory of complex dynamics (see [Mi, Appendix E]), the finite group G gives a holomorphic regular branched covering map, ψ. Since G is a cyclic finite group, ψ has the following form: ψ = h(φ
λ
n ) for some
$$h \in \mathrm{ Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
(also see Theorem 6.6.2
). Write
$$\rho ^{{\ast}}\triangleq \varphi _{\lambda }\circ \rho \circ \varphi _{\lambda }$$
, and then z
n ∘ρ ∗ = z
n since ψ ∘ρ = ψ. Then there is an n-th root ξ of unity such that ρ ∗(z) = ξ z, and hence
$$\displaystyle{\rho (z) =\varphi _{\lambda }(\xi \varphi _{\lambda }(z)).}$$
The above representation for ρ was also obtained in [DSZ, Lemma 8.1]. Note that B ∘φ
λ is also a thin Blaschke product satisfying
$$(B \circ \varphi _{\lambda }) \circ \rho ^{{\ast}} = B \circ \varphi _{\lambda }$$
, and
$$B = (B \circ \varphi _{\lambda }) \circ \varphi _{\lambda }$$
. To finish the proof, it suffices to discuss the case of ρ being a rational rotation, i.e. ρ(z) = ξ z. In this case, we will show that B(z) = B 1(z
n ) for some thin Blaschke product B 1.

For this, observe that
$$\displaystyle{B(\rho ^{j}) = B,\,1 \leq j <n,}$$
which implies that for any z 0 ∈ Z(B), z 0 and ρ
j (z 0) are zeros of B, with the same multiplicity. Therefore, there is a subsequence {z
j } in Z(B) such that the zero sequence of Z(B) is as follows:
$$\displaystyle{z_{0},\rho (z_{0}),\cdots \,,\rho ^{n-1}(z_{ 0});z_{1},\rho (z_{1}),\cdots \,,\rho ^{n-1}(z_{ 1});\cdots \,,}$$
where ρ(z) = ξ z. Note that the zero sequence of
$$\varphi _{z_{k}^{n}}(z^{n})$$
is exactly
$$\displaystyle{z_{k},\rho (z_{k}),\cdots \,,\rho ^{n-1}(z_{ k}).}$$
On the other hand, {z
j } satisfies the Blaschke condition:
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{j=1}^{\infty }(1 -\vert z_{ j}\vert ^{2}) <\infty.}$$
Since
$$1 -\vert z_{j}^{n}\vert ^{2} = 1 - (\vert z_{j}\vert ^{2})^{n} \leq n(1 -\vert z_{j}\vert ^{2}),$$
then
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{j=1}^{\infty }(1 -\vert z_{ j}^{n}\vert ^{2}) <\infty.}$$
That is, {z
j
n } also gives a Blaschke product, denoted by B 1. By omitting a unimodular constant, we have B 1(z
n ) = B(z). Since B is a thin Blaschke product, it’s easy to verify that B 1 is also a thin Blaschke product. The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para:
Note that those thin Blaschke products B in Proposition 5.3.6 have rather special form and for such B,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is clearly nontrivial. In next section, it will be shown that for most thin Blaschke product B,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial. Equivalently, most M
B are irreducible.

Section1.Heading:
Most M
B Are Irreducible
Section1.Para:
In last section, a complete characterization is presented for when
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is nontrivial in terms of Riemann surface associated with this thin Blaschke product B. Based on this, this section develops techniques of analytic continuation for local inverses and then show that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial under a mild condition. That is, for most thin Blaschke products B, M
B has no nontrivial reducing subspace. This is equivalent to say that most M
B are irreducible. As we will see, this fact depends heavily on the geometric property of thin Blaschke products.
The main result of this section, due to Guo and Huang [GH4], is stated as follows.

Para.Emphasis: Suppose B is a thin Blaschke product, and there is a finite subset F of Z(B
) − F is a simple zero of B
has no nontrivial reducing subspace. Equivalently,

Section1.Para:
It seems that either (1) or (2) rarely fails for a thin Blaschke product B. If B has the form B = B 1 ∘ B 2 for two Blaschke products B 1, B 2 and 2 ≤ order B 2 < ∞, then (1) fails. In this case,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is nontrivial since
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) \supseteq \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B_{2}),$$
see Example 5.3.5.
In what follows, we will introduce a notion called gluable, gluable which comes from [GH4] and proves to play an important role in the proof of Theorem 5.4.1.

Now given a holomorphic function ψ defined on
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, set
$$\displaystyle{\mathfrak{F} \triangleq \psi ^{-1} \circ \psi \big (Z(\psi ^{{\prime}})\big),}$$
i.e.
$$\displaystyle{\mathfrak{F} =\{ z \in \mathbb{D};\ \mathrm{there\ is\ a}\ \,w \in \mathbb{D}\ \mathrm{such\ that}\ \psi (w) =\psi (z)\ \mathrm{and}\ \psi ^{{\prime}}(w) = 0\}.}$$
We assume that
$$\mathfrak{F}$$
is relatively closed in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, and its complement set
$$E \triangleq \mathbb{D} - \mathfrak{F}$$
is connected. Special interest is focused on the case when ψ is a thin (or finite) Blaschke product. In this case, Proposition 5.1.1 says that Q is a discrete subset of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, and hence the open set E is connected.
As follows, we introduce some notions from [GH4].

FormalPara.Heading: Definition 5.4.2
FormalPara.Para:
Given a function ψ as above and two points z 1, z 2 ∈ E satisfying
$$\psi (z_{1}) =\psi (z_{2})(z_{1}\neq z_{2})$$
, if there are two paths σ 1 and σ 2 satisfying the following
(a)
σ
i (0) = z
i for i = 1, 2, σ 1(1) = σ 2(1).
(b)
ψ(σ 1(t)) = ψ(σ 2(t)), 0 ≤ t ≤ 1;
(c)
For 0 ≤ t < 1, σ
i (t) ∈ E, i = 1, 2,

then z 1 and z 2 are directly ψ-glued, denoted by
$$z_{1}\stackrel{\psi }{\simeq }z_{2}$$
. directly ψ-glued In addition, we make the convention that z 1 is directly ψ-glued to itself, i.e.
$$z_{1}\stackrel{\psi }{\simeq }z_{1}$$
.

Section1.Para:
In Definition 5.4.2, the conditions (a)–(c) imply that
$$\psi ^{{\prime}}(\sigma _{1}(1)) = 0$$
. To see this, assume conversely that ψ
′ (σ 1(1)) ≠ 0. Let ρ be a local inverse of ψ defined on a neighborhood of σ 1(0) and ρ(σ 1(0)) = σ 2(0). Then by (b) and (c), the continuous map
$$\displaystyle{(t,\sigma _{1}(t))\mapsto \sigma _{2}(t),\,t \in [0,1]}$$
naturally induces an analytic continuation
$$\tilde{\rho }$$
of ρ along σ 1, satisfying
$$\tilde{\rho }(\sigma _{1}(1)) =\sigma _{2}(1)$$
. Since σ 1(1) = σ 2(1), locally
$$\tilde{\rho }$$
equals the identity map. By the uniqueness of analytic continuation, ρ is also the identity map, forcing σ 1(0) = σ 2(0), i.e. z 1 = z 2. This is a contradiction. Therefore, ψ
′ (σ 1(1)) = 0.

Also, in Definition 5.4.2 one can require that
$$\displaystyle{\psi (\sigma _{i}(t))\neq \psi (z_{1}),\ 0 <t <1,}$$
for each i. For this, just replace these paths σ
i with a small permutation of σ
i if ψ(σ
i (t)) ≠ ψ(z 1) holds for some t ∈ (0, 1).
We also need the following.

FormalPara.Heading: Definition 5.4.3
FormalPara.Para:
For a sub-domain
$$\Omega$$
of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, if there is a finite sequence z 0, z 1, ⋯ , z
k in
$$\Omega$$
, such that
$$\displaystyle{z_{j}\stackrel{\psi }{\simeq }z_{j+1},\,\ 0 \leq j \leq k - 1,}$$
and all related paths σ
i in Definition 5.4.2 can be chosen in
$$\Omega$$
, then z 0 and z
k are called ψ-glued on
$$\Omega$$
, denoted by
$$z_{0}\stackrel{\psi \vert _{\Omega }}{\sim }z_{k}$$
; in short,
$$z_{0}\stackrel{\Omega }{\sim }z_{k}$$
or z 0 ∼ z
k . If
$$w\stackrel{\Omega }{\sim }z$$
for all
$$z \in \psi ^{-1} \circ \psi (w) \cap \Omega$$
, then
$$\Omega$$
is called ψ-glued with respect to w.
ψ-glued domain with respect to w
In particular, if
$$\mathbb{D}$$
is ψ-glued with respect to w, then ψ is called gluable with respect to w.

Section1.Para: If ψ is gluable with respect to w for all w ∈ E, then ψ is called gluable.

By Definition 5.4.2, each univalent function ψ is gluable. For more examples, write B(z) = z
n (n ≥ 2). Then the only critical point of B is 0, and
$$E = \mathbb{D} -\{ 0\}$$
. For two different points z 1, z 2 ∈ E with B(z 1) = B(z 2), define
$$\sigma _{i}(t) = (1 - t)z_{i}$$
, i = 1, 2. It is easy to verify conditions (a), (b) and (c) in Definition 5.4.2 hold, and thus
$$z_{1}\stackrel{\psi }{\simeq }z_{2}$$
. Therefore, B is gluable. In general, we have the following result [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: Each finite Blaschke product B is gluable.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para: Given a point z 0 in E, we must show that B is gluable with respect to z 0. Since for each Möbius map φ, the gluable property of φ ∘ B is equivalent to that of B (with respect to z 0), we may assume that B(z 0) = 0.

Write order
$$B = n + 1$$
and
$$\displaystyle{B^{-1} \circ B(z_{ 0}) =\{ z_{0},z_{1},\cdots \,,z_{n}\}.}$$
For each r ∈ (0, 1), consider the components
$$\mathcal{J}_{i,r}$$
of {z: | B(z) | < r} containing z
i (0 ≤ i ≤ n). Clearly, for enough small r > 0, those
$$\mathcal{J}_{i,r}$$
are pairwise disjoint and
$$\displaystyle{\{z: \vert B(z)\vert <r\} =\bigsqcup _{ i=0}^{n}\mathcal{J}_{ i,r}.}$$
Since each
$$\mathcal{J}_{i,r}$$
contains exactly one z
i , it must be directly B-glued. Also, note that by the maximal modulus principle, for 0 < s < 1, any component
$$\mathcal{J}_{i,s}$$
of {z: | B(z) | < s} is simply connected; and the number N(s) of the components
$$\{\mathcal{J}_{i,s}\}$$
decreases in s.

Below, we will enlarge r and make induction on the number of B-glued components of {z: | B(z) | < r}. By standard analysis, one can show that there exist a number t(0 < t < 1) satisfying the following:
(1)
For any r with 0 < r < t, any two of the components
$$\mathcal{J}_{i,r}$$
are disjoint;
(2)
There are at least two distinct i and i
′ such that
$$\overline{\mathcal{J}_{i,t}} \cup \overline{\mathcal{J}_{i^{{\prime}},t}}$$
is connected.

Now we get m(m < n + 1) components of
$$\cup _{i=0}^{n}\overline{\mathcal{J}_{i,t}}$$
, and denote by η the minimal distance between any two components among them. Write
$$\varepsilon = \frac{\eta } {2}$$
and there is a constant δ > 0 such that
$$\displaystyle{\{z \in \mathbb{D}: \vert B(z)\vert <t+\delta \} \subseteq \cup _{i}O(\mathcal{J}_{i,t},\varepsilon ),}$$
where
$$\displaystyle{O(\mathcal{J}_{i,t},\varepsilon ) \triangleq \{ w \in \mathbb{D}:\,\mathrm{ there\ \ is\ \ a\ \ point}\ \ z \in \mathcal{J}_{i,t}\ \ \mathrm{such\ \ that}\ \ \vert z - w\vert <\varepsilon \}.}$$
Then there are exactly m components of
$$\cup _{i}\mathcal{J}_{i,t+\delta },$$
and we deduce that if
$$\Omega$$
is a component of
$$\cup _{i}\mathcal{J}_{i,t+\delta }$$
contains z
j , then
$$\Omega$$
is B-glued with respect to z
j .

To see this, note that for any s(0 < s < 1),
$$\mathcal{J}_{i,s}$$
is simply connected, and its boundary
$$\partial \mathcal{J}_{i,s}$$
must be a Jordan curve satisfying
$$\displaystyle{\partial \mathcal{J}_{i,s} \subseteq \{ z: \vert B(z)\vert = s\}.}$$
Then by (2) there is at least one point
$$w \in \overline{\mathcal{J}_{i,t}} \cap \overline{\mathcal{J}_{i^{{\prime}},t}},$$
see Fig. 5.2.
Fig. 5.2
Gluable property of B

Let
$$\Omega$$
denote the component of
$$\cup _{i}\mathcal{J}_{i,t+\delta }$$
that contains w. Since
$$\displaystyle{B(E) = \mathbb{D} -\mathcal{E}_{B},}$$
by Proposition 5.1.1 B(E) is connected. Thus we can pick a simple curve σ such that
$$\sigma -\{B(w)\} \subseteq B(E) \cap t\mathbb{D}$$
, and σ connects B(z 0) with B(w). Since
$$B^{-1}(\sigma -\{B(w)\})$$
consists of disjoint arcs, there exists at least one curve γ
i in
$$\overline{\mathcal{J}_{i,t}}$$
and another
$$\gamma _{i^{{\prime}}}$$
in
$$\overline{\mathcal{J}_{i^{{\prime}},t}}$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{B(\gamma _{i}) = B(\gamma _{i^{{\prime}}}) =\sigma,}$$
where
$$\gamma _{i}(1) =\gamma _{i^{{\prime}}}(1) = w$$
and
$$\displaystyle{\gamma _{i}(0) = z_{i}\ \ \mathrm{and}\ \ \gamma _{i^{{\prime}}}(0) = z_{i^{{\prime}}}.}$$
Therefore,
$$\Omega$$
is B-glued with respect to z
i . Similarly, any other component of
$$\cup _{i}\mathcal{J}_{i,t+\delta }$$
are also B-glued, as desired.

Noting that m < n + 1, we have reduced the number of those B-glued components. The next step is to find some t
′ such that (1) and (2) holds, and the following discussion as the same as the above two paragraphs. After finite procedures, we come to the case of m = 2; and by repeating the above procedure, one can prove that there is some r ∈ (0, 1) such that {z: | B(z) | < r} is itself B-glued with respect to z 0; and thus
$$\mathbb{D}$$
is also B-glued. In another word, B is gluable. The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para:
Let us make a sketch of the proof of Proposition 5.4.4. For a finite Blaschke product B, write
$$\displaystyle{B^{-1} \circ B(z_{ 0}) =\{ z_{0},z_{1},\cdots \,,z_{n}\}.}$$
First we have only small B-glued components of {z: | B(z) | < r}, and those points z
k in a same component
$$\Omega$$
are B-glued on
$$\Omega$$
. To glue two points z
j and z
k in different components, we need “longer” paths as in Definition 5.4.2. The idea is to enlarge r and
$$\Omega$$
, and then it is possible to glue z
j and z
k . Finally, we get an sufficiently large component that glues all z
k .
We have naturally a corollary and generalization of Proposition 5.4.4.

Para.Emphasis: Each thin Blaschke product is gluable.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Assume that B is a thin Blaschke product. Recall that
$$\displaystyle{E =\{ z \in \mathbb{D};\mathrm{there\ is\ no}\ w\ \mathrm{such\ that}\ B(w) = B(z)\ \mathrm{and}\ B^{{\prime}}(w) = 0\}.}$$
Now fix a z 0 ∈ E and write
$$\displaystyle{B^{-1}(B(z_{ 0})) =\{ z_{n}: n = 0,1,\cdots \,\}.}$$
We will show that z 0 ∼ z
k for each given k.

To see this, set r = max{ | z
i | : 0 ≤ i ≤ k} and put
$$\displaystyle{t^{{\prime}} =\max \{ \vert B(z)\vert: \vert z\vert \leq r\}.}$$
In the proof of Proposition 5.3.4, the last but one paragraph shows that there is a number t in (t
′ , 1) such that
$$B\vert _{\Omega _{t}}: \Omega _{t} \rightarrow t\mathbb{D}$$
is a proper map; furthermore, there is a biholomorphic map
$$f: \mathbb{D} \rightarrow \Omega _{t}$$
and a finite Blaschke product B 0 such that B ∘ f = tB 0. Then by Proposition 5.4.4 B 0 is gluable on
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, then so is B ∘ f. By the biholomorphicity of f, it follows that
$$\Omega _{t}$$
is B-glued with respect to z 0. Since
$$\{z_{0},\cdots \,,z_{k}\} \subseteq \Omega _{t},$$
then
$$\displaystyle{z_{0}\stackrel{\Omega _{t}}{\sim }z_{j},j = 0,\cdots \,,k,}$$
and hence
$$\displaystyle{z_{0}\stackrel{\mathbb{D}}{\sim }z_{k}.}$$
By arbitrariness of k,
$$\mathbb{D}$$
is B-glued with respect to z 0. By the arbitrariness of z 0, B is gluable. The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para:
In what follows, Bochner’s theorem [Wa1, Wa2] Bochner’s theorem will be useful. For a holomorphic function ψ, if ψ
′ (w 0) = 0, then w 0 is called a critical point
critical point of ψ. For a function ψ over
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, all critical points consists of a set, denoted by
$$\displaystyle{Z(\psi ^{{\prime}}) =\{ z \in \mathbb{D}:\ \psi ^{{\prime}}(z) = 0\}.}$$

Para.Emphasis: If B is a finite Blaschke product with order n, then the critical set Z(B
, and B has exactly n − 1 critical points, counting multiplicity.

Section1.Para: Using Bochner’s theorem, we give the following.

FormalPara.Heading: Remark 5.4.7
FormalPara.Para:
For a thin Blaschke product B, Z(B
′ ) is always an infinite set. To see this, let {z
j } denote the zeros of B. By the proof of Proposition 5.3.4, for each n there exists a component
$$\Omega _{r}$$
of
$$\{z \in \mathbb{D};\vert B(z)\vert <r\}$$
satisfying
$$\overline{\Omega _{r}} \subseteq \mathbb{D}$$
and
$$\displaystyle{z_{j} \in \Omega _{r},\,j = 0,\cdots \,,n;}$$
$$B\vert _{\Omega _{r}}: \Omega _{r} \rightarrow r\mathbb{D}$$
is a k-folds (k ≥ n + 1) proper map. In fact, we may regard
$$B\vert _{\Omega _{r}}$$
as a finite Blaschke product with order k. Then by Bochner’s theorem,
$$(B\vert _{\Omega _{r}})^{{\prime}}$$
has exactly
$$k - 1(k - 1 \geq n)$$
zero points, counting multiplicity. By the arbitrariness of n, B
′ has infinitely many zeros on
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. Also, this gives a picture that describes how a thin Blaschke product B is obtained by “gluing” finite Blaschke products.

Section1.Para:
Below, B denotes a thin or finite Blaschke product. For any component G[ρ] of S
B , if (z 0, w 0) ∈ G[ρ], then we also write G[(z 0 ,w 0 )] for G[ρ], and [(z 0 ,w 0 )] for [ρ].

The following indicates a relation between the gluable property of B and the geometry of components in S
B [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: Let B denote a thin or finite Blaschke product. Given z
, suppose there are three paths σ

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Before giving the proof, we introduce some notations. As mentioned before, a curve means a continuous map from [0, 1] into
$$\mathbb{C}$$
. For a curve σ, σ −1 denotes its inverse, defined by
$$\displaystyle{\sigma ^{-1}(t) =\sigma (1 - t),\,0 \leq t \leq 1.}$$
If γ is another curve satisfying γ(0) = σ(1), then the product σ ♯ γ of σ and γ is defined by
$$\displaystyle{\sigma \sharp \gamma (t) =\sigma (2t),\,0 \leq t <\frac{1} {2},}$$
For simplicity, we write σ γ for σ ♯ γ, and σ
m for the m-th product of σ.

Suppose the conditions (1)–(3) in Lemma 5.4.8 hold. Without loss of generality, we assume that
$$\sigma _{1}(1) = 0 = B(\sigma _{1}(1)).$$
From (1) and the comments below Definition 5.4.2, we have B
′ (σ 1(1)) = 0. Then by Böttcher’s theorem, there is local holomorphic change of coordinate w = φ(z) defined on a neighborhood of σ 1(1), such that
$$\varphi \circ B \circ \varphi ^{-1}(w) = w^{n}$$
. This implies that there are n disjoint paths
$$\displaystyle{\gamma _{1},\cdots \,,\gamma _{n}}$$
whose images are contained in a small neighborhood of 0 (see Fig. 5.3), and a loop σ on a neighborhood of σ 0(1) such that:
Fig. 5.3
Analytic continuation and gluable property
(a)
$$\gamma _{j}(1) =\gamma _{j+1}(0),j = 1,\cdots \,,n - 1\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \gamma _{n}(1) =\gamma _{1}(0)$$
;
(b)
$$B(\sigma (t)) = B(\gamma _{j}(t)),0 \leq t \leq 1,j = 1,\cdots \,,n$$
;
(c)
For some enough large t ∗ ∈ (0, 1), σ(0) = σ 0(t ∗), σ 1(t ∗) = γ 1(0) and
$$\sigma _{2}(t^{{\ast}}) =\gamma _{j_{0}}(1)$$
holds for some j 0(1 ≤ j 0 ≤ n).

Now let
$$\widehat{\sigma _{i}}$$
denote the segment of the loop σ
i connecting σ
i (0) with σ
i (t ∗) for i = 0, 1, 2. Precisely, put
$$\displaystyle{\widehat{\sigma _{i}}(t) =\sigma _{i}(t^{{\ast}}t),\,0 \leq t \leq 1,\ \ i = 0,1,2.}$$

Note that for any j, there always exists an m such that
$$\displaystyle{\sigma ^{m}(t)\mapsto \big(\gamma _{ j}\cdots \gamma _{1}\big)(t)}$$
induces a natural analytic continuation along the loop σ
m . Let m 0 be the integer corresponding to j = j 0 and consider the loop
$$\tilde{\sigma }\triangleq \widehat{\sigma _{0}}^{-1}\sigma ^{m_{0}}\widehat{\sigma _{0}}$$
. Also, there is a path
$$\displaystyle{\tilde{\gamma }\triangleq \widehat{\sigma _{2}}^{-1}\gamma _{ j_{0}}\cdots \gamma _{2}\gamma _{1}\widehat{\sigma _{1}}}$$
which connects z 1 with z 2. Then one can show that
$$\tilde{\sigma }(t)\mapsto \tilde{\gamma }(t)$$
naturally gives an analytic continuation along the loop
$$\tilde{\sigma }.$$
Since
$$G[(\tilde{\sigma }(0),\tilde{\gamma }(0))] = G[(\tilde{\sigma }(1),\tilde{\gamma }(1))]$$
and
$$\displaystyle{\tilde{\sigma }(0) =\tilde{\sigma } (1) = z_{0},\tilde{\gamma }(0) = z_{1}\ \,\mathrm{and}\ \,\tilde{\gamma }(1) = z_{2},}$$
we have G[(z 0, z 1)] = G[(z 0, z 1)]. The proof of Lemma 5.4.8 is complete. □

Section1.Para: We also need the following lemma [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: Let B be a thin or finite Blaschke product. With the assumptions in Theorem
and F being empty, assume that

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Inspired by the proofs of Proposition 5.4.4 and Corollary 5.4.5, we first deal with the following special case: there are two different components
$$\Omega _{1}$$
and
$$\Omega _{2}$$
of {z: | B(z) | < t} such that
$$\displaystyle{\widehat{z_{i}} \in \Omega _{i},\quad i = 1,2;}$$
and there is a point
$$z^{{\prime}}\in Z(B^{{\prime}})$$
such that
$$z^{{\prime}}\in \partial \Omega _{1} \cap \partial \Omega _{2}$$
, see Fig. 5.4.
Fig. 5.4
B −1(σ[0, 1])

Clearly, | B(z
′ ) | = t. Now we can find a simple curve σ connecting
$$B(\widehat{z_{1}})$$
with B(z
′ ), satisfying
$$\sigma [0,1) \subseteq E \cap t\mathbb{D}$$
. Since B −1(σ[0, 1)) consists of disjoint arcs, among which the endpoints are
$$\widehat{z_{0}},\widehat{z_{1}}$$
and
$$\widehat{z_{2}}$$
, respectively. Thus, there are three curves σ
i with endpoints
$$\widehat{z_{i}}(i = 0,1,2)$$
such that 5.23
$$\displaystyle{ B \circ \sigma _{i}(t) =\sigma (t),0 \leq t \leq 1,i = 0,1,2. }$$
Note that
$$\sigma _{1}(1) =\sigma _{2}(1) = z^{{\prime}}$$
, and then σ 0(1) ≠ z
′ . Otherwise, by the theory of complex analysis B(⋅ ) − B(z
′ ) would have the order ≥ 3 at the zero z
′ . Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{B^{{\prime}}(z^{{\prime}}) = B^{{\prime\prime}}(z^{{\prime}}) = 0,}$$
which is a contradiction to the assumption that B
′ has only simple zeros. Since
$$B\vert _{Z(B^{{\prime}})}$$
is injective, it follows from (5.23) that B
′ (σ 0(1)) ≠ 0. Then by Lemma 5.4.8,
$$G[(\widehat{z_{0}},\widehat{z_{1}})] = G[(\widehat{z_{0}},\widehat{z_{2}})]$$
, as desired.
The general case can be done as above, with a bit modification. □

Section1.Para: Now we are ready to give the proof of Theorem 5.4.1.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof of Theorem 5.4.1
FormalPara.Para:
The proof is from [GH4]. We will show that S
B has no nontrivial component of finite multiplicity, and then apply Proposition 5.2.8 to finish the proof. □

Section1.Para:
In fact, a generalization of Frostman’s theorem [Ru4] states that for each nonconstant function
$$h \in H^{\infty }(\mathbb{D})$$
, the inner part of h − h(λ) is a Blaschke product with distinct zeros, except for λ in a set of capacity zero. Then by Proposition 5.1.4(2), we may assume that B is a thin Blaschke product of simple zeros {z
j }, without any change of the assumption of Theorem 5.4.1. The proof is divided into two steps because of its length.

ItemContent.Para: Step I. We will prove Theorem 5.4.1 in the case where F = ∅.

Section1.Para:
In this case, draw a graph, {z
n } being all the vertices. For some preliminaries of the graph theory, one may refer to [Hat, pp. 83–86]. If
$$z_{j}\stackrel{B}{\simeq }z_{k}$$
, then by Lemma 5.4.9
5.24
$$\displaystyle{ G[(z_{i},z_{j})] = G[(z_{i},z_{k})],\quad \mathrm{if}\quad z_{i}\neq z_{j}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad z_{i}\neq z_{k}. }$$
For the pair (z
j , z
k ) with
$$z_{j}\stackrel{B}{\simeq }z_{k}$$
, draw an abstract edge between z
j and z
k , called an abstract ∗-arc. All different ∗-arcs are assumed to be disjoint. This can be done because all z
j are in
$$\mathbb{C}$$
, which can be regarded as a subspace of
$$\mathbb{R}^{3}$$
; and all
$${\ast}$$
-arcs are taken as curves in
$$\mathbb{R}^{3}$$
.

By the geometry of B (see the details in proofs of Proposition 5.4.4 and Corollary 5.4.5), such ∗-arcs yields an abstract path (consisting of several adjoining ∗-arcs) connecting any two given points in {z
n }, see Fig. 5.5.
Fig. 5.5
Tree of ∗-arcs

Therefore, all points z
n and ∗-arcs consists of a connected graph, S. We may assume that S is simply-connected, since by the graph theory, any connected graph contains a contractible (and thus simply-connected) subgraph, which has all vertices of S. This subgraph is called a maximal tree [Hat, p. 84, Proposition 1A.1]. For each connected subset
$$\Gamma \subseteq \{ z_{n}\}$$
(with some ∗-arcs), if
$$z \in \{ z_{n}\} - \Gamma$$
, then by (5.24) it is not difficult to see that
$$G[(z,\lambda ^{{\prime}})] = G[(z,\lambda ^{{\prime\prime}})]$$
whenever
$$\lambda ^{{\prime}},\lambda ^{{\prime\prime}}\in \Gamma.$$
Then one can write
$$G[(z,\Gamma )]$$
to denote G[(z, λ
′ )], and we caution the reader that
$$G[(z,\Gamma )]$$
may contain (z, z
n ) for some
$$z_{n}\not\in \Gamma.$$

Now pick one w ∈ { z
n }. In the graph S, delete the vertex w and all ∗-arcs beginning at w, and the remaining consists of finitely or infinitely many connected components
$$\Gamma _{i}$$
. If each component contains infinitely many points z
j , then by Lemma 5.4.9, except for the identity component G[(w, w)] ≡ G[z], all other components
$$G[(w,\Gamma _{i})]$$
of S
B are infinite; that is,
$$\displaystyle{\sharp G[(w,\Gamma _{i})] = \infty.}$$
In this case we are done by Proposition 5.2.8. Otherwise, there is one component
$$\Gamma ^{{\ast}}$$
consisting of only finite points. Since S is a tree and
$$\Gamma ^{{\ast}}\subseteq S$$
, then
$$\Gamma ^{{\ast}}$$
is also a tree. We distinguish two cases:
Case I
$$\sharp \Gamma ^{{\ast}}\geq 2$$
. In this case, one can find an endpoint w ∗ of
$$\Gamma ^{{\ast}}$$
. Replacing w with w ∗, from the reasoning of the above paragraph it follows that there are only two components: the identity component and
$$G[(w^{{\ast}},\Gamma )]$$
, which must be infinite. Thus, the only finite component of S
B is the identity component. By Proposition 5.2.8,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial, and M
B has no nontrivial reducing subspace.
Case II
$$\sharp \Gamma ^{{\ast}} = 1$$
. In this case, write
$$\Gamma ^{{\ast}} =\{ w^{{\ast}}\}$$
and replace w with w ∗. By the reasoning as in Case I, one deduces that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial, and M
B has no nontrivial reducing subspace. Thus, the case of F being empty is done.
Step II. To complete the proof of Theorem 5.4.1, we must show that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast} } (B)$$
is trivial in the case where F ≠ ∅.

Assume that F ≠ ∅. We also have the connected graph S as in Step I. Furthermore, one can construct a connected sub-graph
$$\Gamma _{0}$$
(related with F) of S such that
1.
$$\Gamma _{0}$$
contains only finitely many vertices;
2.
in the case of F ≠ ∅, Lemma 5.4.9 still holds provided that
$$\widehat{z_{0}}\not\in \Gamma _{0}.$$

In fact, put
$$\displaystyle{t^{{\prime}} =\max \{ \vert B(z)\vert: z \in F\}.}$$
Following the proof of Proposition 5.3.4, one can take a number t such that
$$\displaystyle{t\not\in \{\vert B(z)\vert: z \in Z(B^{{\prime}})\}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad t^{{\prime}} <t <1.}$$
Let
$$\Omega _{t}$$
denote the component of {z: | B(z) | < t} containing F. Then
$$\Omega _{t}$$
is a simply-connected domain; and there is a biholomorphic map
$$f: \mathbb{D} \rightarrow \Omega _{t}$$
, and a finite Blaschke product B 0 such that B ∘ f = tB 0. Put
$$\displaystyle{\Gamma _{0} =\{ z_{j} \in \Omega _{t}: j \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}\},}$$
which is clearly a finite set. Observe that
$$\Omega _{t}$$
is B-glued with respect to z
j for any
$$z_{j} \in \Gamma _{0},$$
which implies that
$$\Gamma _{0}$$
is connected. Then one can follow the proof of the claim in Step 1, with a bit modification, to deduce that
$$G[(\widehat{z_{0}},\widehat{z_{1}})] = G[(\widehat{z_{0}},\widehat{z_{2}})]$$
. To be precise, as one construct the simple curve σ connecting
$$B(\widehat{z_{1}})$$
with B(z
′ ), one may require that
$$\sigma [0,1) \subseteq E \cap \Omega _{t}$$
. Since B −1(σ[0, 1)) consists of disjoint arcs, among which the endpoints are
$$\widehat{z_{0}},\widehat{z_{1}}$$
and
$$\widehat{z_{2}}$$
, respectively; and there are three curves σ
i with endpoints
$$\widehat{z_{i}}(i = 0,1,2)$$
such that 5.25
$$\displaystyle{ B \circ \sigma _{i}(t) =\sigma (t),0 \leq t \leq 1,i = 0,1,2. }$$
Since
$$\sigma _{0}(0) =\widehat{ z_{0}}\not\in \Omega _{t}$$
and
$$\Omega _{t}$$
is a component of {z: | B(z) | < t}, σ 0 ∩ Ω
t = ∅. Then we deduce that
$$\sigma _{0}(1)\neq z^{{\prime}}$$
because
$$z^{{\prime}}\in \Omega _{t}$$
. Since
$$\sigma _{1}(1) =\sigma _{2}(1) = z^{{\prime}}$$
, by (5.25) and the discussion below Definition 5.4.2,
$$\displaystyle{B^{{\prime}}(z^{{\prime}}) = 0.}$$
Since
$$\sigma _{0} \cap \Omega _{t} =\emptyset,$$
$$\displaystyle{\sigma _{0}(1)\not\in F.}$$
Since
$$B\vert _{Z(B^{{\prime}})-F}$$
is injective, it follows from (5.25) and
$$B^{{\prime}}(z^{{\prime}}) = 0$$
that
$$\displaystyle{B^{{\prime}}(\sigma _{ 0}(1))\neq 0.}$$
Then by Lemma 5.4.8,
$$G[(\widehat{z_{0}},\widehat{z_{1}})] = G[(\widehat{z_{0}},\widehat{z_{2}})]$$
, as desired.

Now regard
$$\Gamma _{0}$$
as one “point” or a whole body. Delete
$$\Gamma _{0}$$
and consider the remaining part
$$S - \Gamma _{0}$$
. If there is some component containing only finitely many points, then by similar discussion as Case I, one can show that the only finite component of S
B is the identity component and thus
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial. Otherwise, each component of
$$S - \Gamma _{0}$$
has infinitely many points. In this situation, as follows one can show that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial.

In fact, there are several situations to deal with. Firstly, if
$$S - \Gamma _{0}$$
has more than two components each with infinitely many points, then let
$$\Gamma _{1}$$
be such a component and pick
$$w \in \Gamma _{1}$$
(this w plays the same role as the point w ∈ { z
n } in Step I). Regarding
$$\Gamma _{0}$$
as one “point”, the conclusion follows from the same discussion as in the case where F = ∅.

Secondly, if
$$S - \Gamma _{0}$$
is a connected graph with infinitely many points, then rewrite
$$\Gamma _{1} = S - \Gamma _{0}$$
and pick a point w from
$$\Gamma _{1}.$$
If each component of S −{ w} has infinitely many points, or if S −{ w} has a finite component which has no intersection with
$$\Gamma _{0},$$
then the conclusion also follows from the same discussion as in the case where F = ∅. The remaining case is that S −{ w} has exactly one finite component which necessarily contains
$$\Gamma _{0}.$$
Thus, we may assume that for each
$$\hat{w} \in S - \Gamma _{0}$$
,
$$S -\{\hat{ w}\}$$
has exactly one finite component which necessarily contains
$$\Gamma _{0};$$
otherwise, it can be done by the above discussions. From this property of
$$\Gamma _{0},$$
it is not difficult to see that S looks like a half-line, with
$$\Gamma _{0}$$
the endpoint, see Fig. 5.6, and the proof reduces to this case. Assume conversely that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is nontrivial. Then by Proposition 5.2.8, S
B must contain one nontrivial component of finite multiplicity. Let w be the point next to
$$\Gamma _{0}$$
in S, the only possible components of S
B are as follows: the identity component G[(w, w)], one infinite component and one finite component
$$G[(w,\Gamma _{0})]$$
with multiplicity
$$n = \sharp \Gamma _{0}$$
.
Fig. 5.6
Tree like a half line

However, if we denote by w
′ the point next to w, then the only nontrivial finite component is
$$\displaystyle{G[(w^{{\prime}},\Gamma _{ 0})] = G[(w^{{\prime}},\Gamma _{ 0} \cup \{ w\})]}$$
whose multiplicity is not less than
$$\sharp \Gamma _{0} + 1$$
. This derives a contradiction since there is exactly one nontrivial finite component
$$\displaystyle{G[(w^{{\prime}},\Gamma _{ 0})] = G[(w,\Gamma _{0})].}$$

Therefore,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial, and hence M
B has no nontrivial reducing subspace. The proof is complete. □

Let us have a look at the above proof. In the case of a thin Blaschke product, we present a finite subset
$$\Gamma _{0}$$
of S, which is related to a finite set F. However, if B is a finite Blaschke product, it is probable that
$$\Gamma _{0} = S,$$
which would spoil the proof of Theorem 5.4.1.

In fact, for a finite Blaschke product B, S is a graph of finite vertices. In the case of F being empty, applying the proof of Theorem 5.4.1 shows that there is a point w and a connected subgraph
$$\Gamma$$
such that S consists of
$$\Gamma$$
and w. Then S
B has exactly two components: G[z] and
$$G[(w,\Gamma )],$$
which are necessarily of finite multiplicities since B is of finite order. Thus, we get the following result.

Para.Emphasis: For a finite Blaschke product B, if the conditions in Theorem
hold with F being empty, then M

Section1.Para:
Very Recently, Douglas et al. [DPW] showed that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is abelian and is ∗-isomorphic to q-th direct sum
$$\mathbb{C} \oplus \cdots \oplus \mathbb{C}$$
of
$$\mathbb{C}$$
, where q (2 ≤ q ≤ n) is the number of components of the Riemann surface S
B . Corollary 5.4.10 shows that in most cases q = 2, and thus gives some support for Theorem 4.2.1
in the sense of probability. In this case, write
$$M_{0} = \overline{span\{B^{{\prime}}B^{n}: n = 0,1,\cdots \,\}}$$
, and then M 0 and M 0 ⊥ are the only minimal reducing subspaces for M
B [SZ2, Theorem 15].

In Sect. 5.7 in Chap. 5
, we will see more examples of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
where B dissatisfies the assumption of Corollary 5.4.10, see Proposition 5.8.1 and Example 5.8.2.

Section1.Heading: The Construction of an Example
Section1.Para:
Last section shows that for most thin Blaschke products B,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial. This section will give a construction of such a thin Blaschke product B that M
B has no nontrivial reducing subspace.
We need the following lemma, which appeared in [GH4].

Section1.Para:
By the proof of Lemma 5.5.1, one will see that with an appropriate choice of s, if the restriction
$$B\vert _{Z(B^{{\prime}})}$$
of B on Z(B
′ ) is injective, then the restriction of B φ
λ on
$$Z\big((B\varphi _{\lambda })^{{\prime}}\big)$$
is also injective.

Before we give the proof, let us make an observation. For each
$$\lambda \in \mathbb{D} -\{ 0\}$$
and a compact subset K of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
,
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} \vert \varphi _{\lambda }(z) - \frac{\lambda } {\vert \lambda \vert }\vert & \leq & \vert \frac{\lambda -z} {1 -\overline{\lambda }z} -\lambda \vert + \vert \lambda - \frac{\lambda } {\vert \lambda \vert }\vert {}\\ & =& \vert z\frac{1 -\vert \lambda \vert ^{2}} {1 -\overline{\lambda }z} \vert + 1 -\vert \lambda \vert {}\\ &\leq & \frac{\vert z\vert (1 -\vert \lambda \vert ^{2}) + (1 -\vert \lambda \vert )(1 -\vert z\vert )} {1 -\vert z\vert } {}\\ &\leq & 2 \frac{1 -\vert \lambda \vert } {1 -\vert z\vert } \leq \frac{2(1 -\vert \lambda \vert )} {1 - r(K)},\,z \in K, {}\\ \end{array}$$
where
$$r(K) \triangleq \max \{\vert z\vert: z \in K\}$$
. Write
$$\psi _{\lambda } = \dfrac{\vert \lambda \vert } {\lambda } \varphi _{\lambda }$$
, and then 5.26
$$\displaystyle{ \vert \psi _{\lambda }(z) - 1\vert \leq \frac{2(1 -\vert \lambda \vert )} {1 - r(K)},\,z \in K. }$$

FormalPara.Heading: Proof of Lemma 5.5.1
FormalPara.Para: The proof comes from [GH4].

Section1.Para:
Suppose B is a finite Blaschke product with order
$$B \triangleq n \geq 2$$
. If (1) is proved, then one will see that the number s in Lemma 5.5.1 can be enlarged to satisfy (2). To see this, given an r ∈ (0, 1), there is an s such that (1) holds for all
$$\lambda \in \mathbb{D}$$
satisfying | λ | > s. Pick an r
′ ∈ (r, 1) satisfying
$$\displaystyle{r^{{\prime}}>\max \{ \vert z\vert;B^{{\prime}}(z) = 0\},}$$
and choose an
$$r^{{\prime\prime}}\in (0,1)$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{r^{{\prime\prime}}>\max \{ \vert B(z)\vert: \vert z\vert \leq r^{{\prime}}\}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad r^{{\prime\prime}}> r^{{\prime}}> r.}$$
For this r
′ ′ , there is an s
′ ′ (0 < s
′ ′ < 1) such that whenever | λ | > s
′ ′ and
$$\lambda \in \mathbb{D}$$
, there is a critical point w ∗ of B φ
λ such that
$$\displaystyle{\vert B(w^{{\ast}})\varphi _{\lambda }(w^{{\ast}})\vert> r^{{\prime\prime}}.}$$
On another hand, by (5.26) there is an s
′ ∈ (0, 1) satisfying the following: for any
$$\lambda \in \mathbb{D}$$
with | λ | > s
′ ,
$$\displaystyle{\|B\psi _{\lambda } - B\|_{r^{{\prime\prime}}\overline{\mathbb{D}},\infty }}$$
is enough small so that
$$\displaystyle{\|(B\psi _{\lambda })^{{\prime}}- B^{{\prime}}\|_{ r^{{\prime}}\mathbb{T},\infty } <\min \{ \vert B^{{\prime}}(z)\vert: \vert z\vert = r^{{\prime}}\}.}$$
Then applying Rouche’s theorem implies that on
$$r^{{\prime}}\mathbb{D}$$
,
$$\big(B\psi _{\lambda }\big)^{{\prime}}$$
has the same number of zeros as B
′ , counting multiplicity. Since Bochner’s theorem (Theorem 5.4.6) says that each Blaschke product with k zeros has exactly k − 1 critical points in the unit disk
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, counting multiplicity, then
$$\big(B\psi _{\lambda }\big)^{{\prime}}$$
has n − 1 zeros on
$$r^{{\prime}}\mathbb{D}$$
. Again by Bochner’s theorem,
$$\big(B\psi _{\lambda }\big)^{{\prime}}$$
has n zeros in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, and hence there is exactly one zero w 0 outside
$$r^{{\prime}}\mathbb{D}$$
. That is,
$$\displaystyle{\{w_{0}\} = Z\big((B\psi _{\lambda })^{{\prime}}\big) - r^{{\prime}}\mathbb{D},}$$
which gives that
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} r^{{\prime\prime}}&>& \max \{\vert B(z)\vert: \vert z\vert \leq r^{{\prime}}\} {}\\ &\geq & \max \{\vert B\psi _{\lambda }(z)\vert: \vert z\vert \leq r^{{\prime}}\} {}\\ &\geq & \max \{\vert B\psi _{\lambda }(z)\vert: z \in Z\big((B\psi _{\lambda })^{{\prime}}\big) -\{ w_{ 0}\}\}. {}\\ \end{array}$$
As mentioned before, there is a critical point w ∗ of B ψ
λ satisfying
$$\displaystyle{\vert B(w^{{\ast}})\varphi _{\lambda }(w^{{\ast}})\vert> r^{{\prime\prime}}.}$$
Since
$$\displaystyle{r^{{\prime\prime}}>\max \{ \vert B\psi _{\lambda }(z)\vert: z \in Z\big((B\psi _{\lambda })^{{\prime}}\big) -\{ w_{ 0}\}\},}$$
we get w ∗ = w 0. Thus, for any
$$\lambda \in \mathbb{D}$$
with
$$\lambda>\max \{ s^{{\prime}},s^{{\prime\prime}}\}$$
,
$$\displaystyle{\vert B(w_{0})\psi _{\lambda }(w_{0})\vert> r^{{\prime\prime}}>\max \{ \vert B\psi _{\lambda }(z)\vert: z \in Z\big((B\psi _{\lambda })^{{\prime}}\big) -\{ w_{ 0}\}\}.}$$
Also,
$$\vert B(w_{0})\psi _{\lambda }(w_{0})\vert> r$$
since r
′ ′ > r. Therefore, write
$$s =\max \{ s^{{\prime}},s^{{\prime\prime}}\}$$
and then both (1) and (2) hold for any
$$\lambda \in \mathbb{D}$$
with | λ | > s.

It remains to prove (1). Set t 0 = max{ | z | : z ∈ Z(B)} and
$$\displaystyle{t_{1} =\max \{ \vert B(z)\vert;z \in t_{0}\overline{\mathbb{D}}\}.}$$
For any t > t 1, let
$$\Omega _{t}$$
denote the component of {z: | B(z) | < t} containing
$$t_{0}\mathbb{D}$$
. We will see that
$$\displaystyle{\Omega _{t} =\{ z: \vert B(z)\vert <t\}.}$$
The reasoning is as follows. By Lemma 5.1.2,
$$B\vert _{\Omega _{t}}: \Omega _{t} \rightarrow t\mathbb{D}$$
is a proper map. By Proposition 2.1.2
,
$$B\vert _{\Omega _{t}}$$
is a k-folds map for some integer k. Since the restriction
$$\big(B - 0\big)\vert _{\Omega _{t}}$$
has
$$n(n =\mathrm{ order}\,B)$$
zeros, k = n. This implies that there is no component of {z: | B(z) | < t} other than
$$\Omega _{t}$$
. Therefore,
$$\Omega _{t} =\{ z: \vert B(z)\vert <t\}$$
.

Now pick a number t ∗ in (0, 1) such that
$$\displaystyle{t^{{\ast}}>\max \{ \vert z\vert: z \in Z(B^{{\prime}})\}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad t^{{\ast}}> t_{ 1}.}$$
Without loss of generality, we assume that r > t ∗. Write r 0 = r, and pick real numbers r 1 and r 2 satisfying
$$\displaystyle{t^{{\ast}} <r_{ 0} <r_{1} <r_{2} <1.}$$
As mentioned above,
$$\Omega _{r_{j}} =\{ z: \vert B(z)\vert <r_{j}\}(j = 0,1,2).$$
Since
$$\displaystyle{\|B\psi _{\lambda } - B\|_{\Omega _{r_{ 2}},\infty }\leq \|\psi _{\lambda }- 1\|_{\Omega _{r_{ 2}},\infty },}$$
then by (5.26) for enough small
$$\varepsilon> 0$$
, there exists an
$$s \in (r(\overline{\Omega _{r_{2}}}),1)$$
5.27
$$\displaystyle{ \|B\psi _{\lambda } - B\|_{\Omega _{r_{ 2}},\infty } <\varepsilon,\quad \vert \lambda \vert> s. }$$
Let
$$\Omega _{1}$$
and
$$\Omega _{2}$$
denote the components of
$$\displaystyle{\{z: \vert B(z)\psi _{\lambda }(z)\vert <r_{1}\}}$$
containing Z(B) and λ, respectively (see Fig. 5.7). The prescribed
$$\varepsilon$$
in (5.27) can be enough small so that
$$\displaystyle{\Omega _{r_{0}} \subseteq \Omega _{1} \subseteq \Omega _{r_{2}}.}$$
Since
$$\vert \lambda \vert> s> r(\overline{\Omega _{r_{2}}}) \geq r(\overline{\Omega _{1}})$$

$$\Omega _{1}\neq \Omega _{2}$$

$$\Omega _{1} \cap \Omega _{2}$$
is empty. By Lemma 5.1.2 the restrictions of B ψ
λ on
$$\Omega _{1}$$
and
$$\Omega _{2}$$
are proper maps onto
$$r_{1}\mathbb{D}$$
. By (5.27)
$$B\psi _{\lambda }\vert _{\Omega _{1}}$$
has n-folds, and then
$$B\psi _{\lambda }\vert _{\Omega _{2}}$$
is a onefold map, i.e.
$$B\psi _{\lambda }\vert _{\Omega _{2}}$$
is univalent. Combing Bochner’s theorem with Theorem 2.1.3
shows that the derivative of
$$B(z)\psi _{\lambda }$$
has n zeros, with n − 1 zeros in
$$\Omega _{1}$$
, and that the derivative of B(z)ψ
λ never varnishes on
$$\Omega _{2}$$
. Thus, there is exactly one critical point w ∗ satisfying
$$w^{{\ast}}\not\in \Omega _{1}\bigsqcup \Omega _{2}$$
. Since
$$\displaystyle{\{z: \vert B(z)\psi _{\lambda }(z)\vert <r_{1}\} = \Omega _{1}\bigsqcup \Omega _{2},}$$
$$\vert B(w^{{\ast}})\psi _{\lambda }(w^{{\ast}})\vert \geq r_{1}> r$$
, as desired. The proof is complete. □
