Section1.Para:
Let us make an observation. For
$$x \in (0, \frac{1} {2})$$
, we have e 2x < 1 + 4x. Then
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{n=0}^{\infty }(1 + \frac{x} {2^{n}}) =\exp (\sum _{n=0}^{\infty }\ln (1 + \frac{x} {2^{n}})) <\exp (\sum _{n=0}^{\infty } \frac{x} {2^{n}}) <1 + 4x.}$$
Take
$$x = \dfrac{\varepsilon } {2}$$
, and 5.28
$$\displaystyle{ \prod _{n=1}^{\infty }(1 + \frac{\varepsilon } {2^{n}}) <1 + 2\varepsilon,\,0 <\varepsilon <1. }$$
Now let K be a compact subset of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, and pick δ ∈ (0, 1). If {λ
n } is a Blaschke sequence satisfying 5.29
$$\displaystyle{ 1 -\vert \lambda _{n}\vert \leq \frac{\delta (1 - r(K))} {2^{n+2}}, }$$
then by (5.26) we get
$$\displaystyle{\vert \psi _{\lambda _{n}}(z) - 1\vert \leq \frac{\delta } {2^{n+1}},\,z \in K,}$$
where
$$\displaystyle{\psi _{\lambda _{n}}(z) = \frac{\vert \lambda _{n}\vert } {\lambda _{n}} \frac{\lambda _{n} - z} {1 -\overline{\lambda _{n}}z}.}$$
Write
$$\varepsilon _{n}(z) =\psi _{\lambda _{n}}(z) - 1$$
. Then by (5.28)
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} \big\vert \prod _{n}\psi _{\lambda _{n}}(z) - 1\big\vert & =& \big\vert \prod _{n}(1 +\varepsilon _{n}(z)) - 1\big\vert {}\\ & =& \big\vert \sum _{i_{1}<i_{2}<\cdots <i_{k}}\varepsilon _{i_{1}}(z)\varepsilon _{i_{2}}(z)\cdots \varepsilon _{i_{k}}(z)\big\vert {}\\ &\leq & \sum _{i_{1}<i_{2}<\cdots <i_{k}} \frac{\delta } {2^{i_{1}+1}} \frac{\delta } {2^{i_{2}+1}}\cdots \frac{\delta } {2^{i_{k}+1}} {}\\ & =& \prod _{n=1}^{\infty }(1 + \frac{\delta } {2^{n+1}}) - 1 {}\\ & <& 1 +\delta -1 =\delta. {}\\ \end{array}$$
Thus, for any Blaschke product ϕ, if (5.29) holds, then
5.30
$$\displaystyle{ \|\phi \prod _{n}\psi _{\lambda _{n}} -\phi \|_{K,\infty }\leq \delta. }$$
Note that (5.30) also holds if {λ
n } is replaced with any subsequence of {λ
n }.
The construction of B will be the focus of the discussion as follows.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof of Theorem 5.5.3
FormalPara.Para: The proof comes from [GH4].

Section1.Para:
Assume that
$$\lim \limits _{n\rightarrow \infty }\vert z_{n}\vert = 1$$
. First we show that {z
n } contains a thin Blaschke subsequence. To see this, let d denote the hyperbolic metric over the unit disk, and we have
$$\lim \limits _{n\rightarrow \infty }d(z_{k},z_{n}) = 1$$
for each k. Pick two natural numbers m 1 and m 2 such that
$$d(z_{m_{1}},z_{m_{2}})> 1 - \frac{1} {2^{2}},$$
and put
$$w_{j} = z_{m_{j}}(j = 1,2)$$
. In general, we will use induction. Assume that we have n points:
$$\displaystyle{w_{1} = z_{m_{1}},\cdots \,,w_{n} = z_{m_{n}},}$$
and
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{1\leq j<k}d(w_{j},w_{k})> 1 - \frac{1} {(k + 1)^{2}},k = 1,2,\cdots \,,n.}$$
Since
$$\lim \limits _{k\rightarrow \infty }\prod _{1\leq j\leq n}d(w_{j},z_{k}) = 1,$$
there is an integer m
n+1 > m
n such that
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{1\leq j\leq n}d(w_{j},z_{m_{n+1}})> 1 - \frac{1} {(n + 2)^{2}}.}$$
Put
$$w_{n+1} = z_{m_{n+1}}$$
, and the induction is done. Therefore, we have a subsequence {w
n } satisfying
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{1\leq j<k}d(w_{j},w_{k})> 1 - \frac{1} {(k + 1)^{2}},k = 1,2,\cdots \,.}$$
Since
$$\prod _{n\geq 2}(1 - \frac{1} {n^{2}} )> 0,$$
then
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} \prod _{j;j\neq k}d(w_{j},w_{k})& =& \prod _{j<k}d(w_{j},w_{k})\prod _{j>k}d(w_{j},w_{k}) {}\\ & \geq & \big(1 - \frac{1} {(k + 1)^{2}}\big)\prod _{j>k}\big(1 - \frac{1} {(j + 1)^{2}}\big) \rightarrow 1,k \rightarrow \infty. {}\\ \end{array}$$
This immediately shows that {w
n } is a thin Blaschke sequence, as desired.

Now we may assume that {z
n } is itself a thin Blaschke sequence. We will find a subsequence of {z
n } whose Blaschke product B satisfies the conditions (1) and (2) in Theorem 5.4.1 with F = ∅. For this, we will construct a sequence {B
m } of finite Blaschke products with order
$$B_{m} = m + 1$$
and B equals the limit of B
m .

Write
$$\displaystyle{\varphi =\varphi _{z_{1}}\varphi _{z_{2}},}$$
where
$$\displaystyle{\varphi _{\lambda }(z) = \frac{\lambda -z} {1 -\overline{\lambda }z}.}$$
By Theorem 5.4.6, φ has a unique critical point, denoted by w 1. Namely, φ
′ (w 1) = 0. Rewrite B 1 = φ, and one can construct two closed disks
$$\widetilde{K_{1}}$$
, K 1 in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, and a constant δ 1 > 0 satisfying the following:
1.
$$\widetilde{K_{1}}$$
is a closed disk containing
$$\{z: \vert z\vert <\frac{1} {2}\}$$
and w 1.
2.
$$\widetilde{K_{1}} \subseteq \stackrel{\circ }{K_{1}}$$
, δ 1 is enough small such that for any holomorphic function h with
$$\|h - B_{1}\|_{K_{1},\infty } <\delta _{1}$$
,
$$Z(h^{{\prime}}) \cap \widetilde{ K_{1}}$$
contains exactly one point.
3.
Taking δ = δ 1 and K = K 1 in (5.29), there is a subsequence
$$\{z_{n,1}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
of
$$\{z_{n}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
satisfying (5.29).

By induction, suppose we have already constructed a finite Blaschke product B
m with order
$$B_{m} = m + 1$$
such that:
(i)
$$B_{m}\vert _{Z(B_{m}^{{\prime}})}$$
is injective;
(ii)
$$\widetilde{K_{m}}$$
is a closed disk containing both
$$\{z: \vert z\vert <1 - \frac{1} {m+1}\}$$
and Z(B
m
′ ).
(iii)
there is a constant δ
m > 0 and two closed disks
$$\widetilde{K_{m}}$$
and K
m (
$$\widetilde{K_{m}} \subseteq \stackrel{\circ }{K_{m}}$$
) in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
such that for any holomorphic function h with
$$\|h - B_{m}\|_{K_{m},\infty } <\delta _{m}$$
, the restriction of h on
$$Z(h^{{\prime}}) \cap \widetilde{ K_{m}}$$
is injective.
(iv)
Taking δ = δ
m and K = K
m in (5.29), there is a subsequence
$$\{z_{n,m}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
of
$$\{z_{n,m-1}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
satisfying (5.29).

By Lemma 5.5.1, there is a point
$$\lambda \in \{ z_{n,m}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
with 1 − | λ | enough small such that the restriction of B
m
φ
λ on
$$Z\big((B_{m}\varphi _{\lambda })^{{\prime}}\big)$$
is injective. Then put
$$B_{m+1} = B_{m}\psi _{\lambda }$$
; that is, B
m+1 is a constant multiple of B
m
φ
λ . Now write
$$\displaystyle{r =\max \{ \frac{1 + r(K_{m})} {2},1 - \frac{1} {m + 2}\}}$$
and
$$r^{{\prime}} = \frac{1+r} {2}$$
. Set
$$\displaystyle{\widetilde{K_{m+1}} =\{ z: \vert z\vert \leq r\}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad K_{m+1} =\{ z: \vert z\vert \leq r^{{\prime}}\}.}$$
Clearly,
$$\widetilde{K_{m+1}} \subseteq K_{m+1}$$
. By Lemma 5.5.2 we can find a δ
m+1 > 0 such that the similar version of (iii) holds for m + 1. Taking
$$\displaystyle{\delta =\delta _{m+1}\ \ \mathrm{and}\ \ K = K_{m+1}}$$
in (5.29), there is a subsequence
$$\{z_{n,m+1}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
of
$$\{z_{n,m}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
satisfying (5.29). Considering that both z 1, m+1 and λ lie in
$$\{z_{n,m}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
, it is required that z 1, m+1 is behind λ. Now the induction on m is complete.

By induction, it is clear that B
m converges to a thin Blaschke product B. For each fixed n, there is a Blaschke product
$$\widetilde{B_{m}}$$
such that
$$B = B_{m}\widetilde{B_{m}}.$$
Let {λ
k } be the zero sequence of
$$\widetilde{B_{m}}$$
(of course, {λ
k } depends on m). By our construction, {λ
k } is a subsequence of
$$\{z_{n,m}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
, and then by (iv) (5.29) holds:
$$\displaystyle{1 -\vert \lambda _{k}\vert \leq \frac{\delta _{m}(1 - r(K_{m}))} {2^{k+2}}.}$$
Since
$$\widetilde{B_{m}} =\prod _{k}\psi _{\lambda _{k}}$$
, by (5.30) we have
$$\displaystyle{\|B_{m}\widetilde{B_{m}} - B_{m}\|_{K_{m},\infty }\leq \delta _{m}.}$$
That is,
$$\displaystyle{\|B - B_{m}\|_{K_{m},\infty }\leq \delta _{m}.}$$
Thus by (iii),
$$B\vert _{Z(B^{{\prime}})\cap \widetilde{K_{m}}}$$
is injective. Since
$$\widetilde{K_{m}}$$
is an increasing sequence of closed domains whose union is
$$\mathbb{D}$$
,
$$B\vert _{Z(B^{{\prime}})}$$
is injective. Then applying Lemma 5.5.2 shows that
$$B^{{\prime}}\vert _{\widetilde{K_{m}}}$$
has only simple zeros for each m, and hence B
′ has only simple zeros. Thus, B satisfies the assumptions of Theorem 5.4.1, with F being empty. Therefore, the construction of B is complete and the proof is finished. □

Section1.Heading:
Another Proof for a Characterization on
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
Section1.Para:
This section will provide an alternative proof of a weak version of Theorem 5.3.1. Different ideas will prove to be useful in characterizing the adjoint of a bounded operator in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
.

In Theorem 5.2.4, a global representation is obtained for unitary operators S in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
:
$$\displaystyle{Sh(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }c_{ k}h \circ \rho _{k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z),\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in \mathbb{D} - L.}$$
By Proposition 2.5.1
, each operator S in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
has the above form, and by Lemma 5.2.6, one may rewrite S as 5.31
$$\displaystyle{ Sh(z) =\sum _{[\rho ]}\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ]}c_{\rho }h \circ \sigma (z)\sigma ^{{\prime}}(z) \equiv \sum _{ [\rho ]}c_{\rho }\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}h(z),\ h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in E. }$$
The following lemma, due to Guo and Huang [GH4], is our main result in this section.

FormalPara.Heading: Lemma 5.6.1
FormalPara.Para:
Given a thin Blaschke product B, suppose S is an operator in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
with the form (5.31) . If
$$\overline{Z(B)} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}$$
, then
$$\displaystyle{S^{{\ast}}h(z) =\sum _{ [\rho ]}\overline{c_{\rho }}\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ^{-}]}h(z),\ h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in E.}$$
Furthermore, for each ρ such that c ρ ≠ 0, we have ♯[ρ] < ∞ and ♯[ρ − ] < ∞.

Section1.Para: Under a weaker assumption, B is just an interpolating Blaschke product, and in this case, Lemma 5.6.1 also holds, though on a small disk around some zero of B.
To prove Lemma 5.6.1, we need the following claim [GH4].

FormalPara.Heading: Claim
FormalPara.Para:
If
$$\overline{Z(B)} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}$$
, then for any 0 < δ < 1,
$$\overline{B^{-1}(\Delta (0,\delta ))} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}.$$

Section1.Para:
This claim easily follows from a smart observation by the referee of [GH4]: if
$$\overline{Z(B)} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}$$
, then there is an open non-empty arc
$$\gamma \subseteq \mathbb{T}$$
such that B has an analytic continuation across γ and has modulus 1 on γ.

Also, we have an alternative proof for the above claim, as follows. WriteZ(B) = { z
n }. By (5.2), there is an
$$\varepsilon \in (0,1)$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{B^{-1}(\Delta (0,\delta )) \subseteq \bigcup _{ n}\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon ),}$$

Therefore, it suffices to show that
$$\overline{\bigcup _{n}\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon )} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}.$$
For this, assume conversely that
$$\overline{\bigcup _{n}\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon )} \supseteq \mathbb{T}$$
. Since
$$\overline{Z(B)} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}$$
, there is a
$$\zeta \in \mathbb{T}$$
such that
$$\zeta \not\in \overline{Z(B)}.$$
Since
$$\overline{\bigcup _{n}\Delta (z_{n},\varepsilon )} \supseteq \mathbb{T}$$
, there is a sequence {w
k } in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
and a subsequence
$$\{z_{n_{k}}\}$$
of {z
n } such that 5.32
$$\displaystyle{ d(z_{n_{k}},w_{k}) <\varepsilon, }$$
and
$$\displaystyle{\lim _{k\rightarrow \infty }w_{k} =\zeta.}$$
Here,
$$d(z,w) \triangleq \Big\vert \dfrac{z - w} {1 -\overline{z}w}\Big\vert$$
. Since
$$\zeta \not\in \overline{Z(B)}$$
, we have
$$\displaystyle{d(z,\zeta ) = 1,z \in \overline{Z(B)}.}$$
By the continuity of d(z, w), there is an enough small closed disk K centered at ζ such that
$$\displaystyle{d(z,w) \geq \frac{1+\varepsilon } {2},z \in \overline{Z(B)},w \in K.}$$
For enough large k, w
k ∈ K, and then
$$\displaystyle{d(z_{n_{k}},w_{k}) \geq \frac{1+\varepsilon } {2}.}$$
This is a contradiction to (5.32). Therefore,
$$\overline{B^{-1}(\Delta (0,\delta ))} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}.$$
The proof of the claim is complete. □

By the above claim, for each z ∈ E there is always an open neighborhood U (U ⊆ E) of z that admits a complete local inverse, such that
$$\displaystyle{\overline{B^{-1} \circ B(U)} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}.}$$
Then we may stretch U such that
$$\mathbb{C} -\overline{B^{-1} \circ B(U)}$$
is connected. Therefore,

Para.Emphasis: for each z ∈ E, there is an open neighborhood U( U ⊆ E) of z that admits a complete local inverse, and

Section1.Para: With this observation, we can give the proof of Lemma 5.6.1 as below.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof of Lemma 5.6.1
FormalPara.Para: The proof is from [GH4].

Section1.Para:
By Proposition 2.5.1
, each operator in a von Neumann algebra is the finite linear span of its unitary operators. Without loss of generality, assume that S is a unitary operator in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
. Let
$$\widetilde{M_{B}}$$
denote the multiplication operator by B on
$$L^{2}(\mathbb{D},dA)$$
given by
$$\displaystyle{\widetilde{M_{B}}g = Bg,\,g \in L^{2}(\mathbb{D},dA).}$$
If we can show that
$$\widetilde{M_{B}}$$
is the minimal normal extension of M
B , then by Conway [Con2, pp. 435–436, Theorem VIII.2.20] and Douglas et al. [DSZ, pp. 552, 553], for each unitary operator
$$S \in \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
, there exists a unitary operator
$$\tilde{S}$$
defined on
$$L^{2}(\mathbb{D},dA)$$
such that
$$\tilde{S}\vert _{L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})} = S$$
and
$$\tilde{S}$$
commutes with
$$\widetilde{M_{B}}$$
. This will be demonstrated by the following paragraph in detail.

We will show that
$$\widetilde{M_{B}}$$
is the minimal normal extension of M
B . Recall that if A is a subnormal operator on
$$\mathcal{H}$$
and
$$\tilde{A}$$
is a normal extension of A to
$$\mathcal{K}$$
, where
$$\mathcal{H}$$
and
$$\mathcal{K}$$
are Hilbert spaces, then
$$\tilde{A}$$
is a minimal normal extension
minimal normal extension of A if
$$\mathcal{K}$$
equals the norm-closure of
$$span\{\tilde{A}^{{\ast}k}h: h \in \mathcal{H},k \geq 0\}$$
. Now set
$$\displaystyle{K = span\{\widetilde{M_{B}}^{{\ast}k}h;\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),k \geq 0\}.}$$
Define a linear map
$$\tilde{S}$$
on K by requiring that
$$\displaystyle{\tilde{S}(\widetilde{M_{B}}^{{\ast}k}h) =\widetilde{ M_{ B}}^{{\ast}k}Sh,\,\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),k \geq 0.}$$
Since S is a unitary operator, it is easy to check that
$$\tilde{S}$$
is well-defined on K and
$$\tilde{S}$$
commutes with
$$\widetilde{M_{B}}$$
. Note that
$$\tilde{S}$$
is an isometric operator whose range equals K, and thus
$$\tilde{S}$$
can be naturally extended to a unitary operator on the closure
$$\overline{K}$$
of K. Since
$$\displaystyle{K = span\{\widetilde{M_{B}}^{{\ast}k}\widetilde{M_{ B}}^{l}h;\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),k \geq 0,l \geq 0\},}$$
it follows that for any polynomial P,
$$P(B,\overline{B})h \in K$$
. Then applying Stone-Weierstrass’s Theorem shows that for any
$$u \in C(\overline{\mathbb{D}})$$
,
$$u(B)h \in \overline{K}$$
. Lusin’s Theorem states that for each
$$v \in L^{\infty }(\mathbb{D})$$
, there is a uniformly bounded sequence {v
n } in
$$C(\overline{\mathbb{D}})$$
such that {v
n } converges to v in measure. Therefore, for any
$$u \in L^{\infty }(\mathbb{D})$$
,
$$u(B)h \in \overline{K}$$
. In particular, for any open subset U of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
,
$$\displaystyle{\chi _{B^{-1}\circ B(U)}h \in \overline{K}.}$$
As mentioned above, for each z ∈ E there is an open neighborhood U (U ⊆ E) of z that admits a complete local inverse, such that
$$\displaystyle{B^{-1} \circ B(U) =\bigsqcup _{ j}\rho _{j}(U),}$$
and
$$\mathbb{C} -\overline{B^{-1} \circ B(U)}$$
is connected. For each fixed i,
$$\chi _{\rho _{ i}(U)}$$
denotes the characterization function of ρ
i (U). As done in [DSZ], applying the Runge theorem (see Theorem 2.1.18
) shows that there is a sequence of polynomials {p
k } such that p
k converges to
$$\chi _{\rho _{i}(U)}$$
uniformly on the closure of B −1 ∘ B(U). Since
$$\chi _{B^{-1}\circ B(U)}p_{k} \in \overline{K}$$
,
$$\chi _{\rho _{ i}(U)} \in \overline{K}.$$
In particular,
$$\chi _{U} \in \overline{K}.$$
When this U is replaced with any other disk
$$\Delta (\Delta \subseteq U)$$
, we also have
$$\chi _{\Delta } \in \overline{K}$$
. Since all
$$\chi _{\Delta }$$
span a dense subspace of L 2(U),
$$\displaystyle{L^{2}(U) \subseteq \overline{K}.}$$
Since all such open sets U covers
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, we have
$$L^{2}(\mathbb{D}) \subseteq \overline{K}$$
, and hence
$$L^{2}(\mathbb{D}) = \overline{K}$$
. This shows that
$$\widetilde{M_{B}}$$
is exactly the minimal normal extension of M
B , as desired.

Now assume that the unitary operator
$$S \in \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
has the form in (5.31):
$$\displaystyle{Sh(z) =\sum _{[\rho ]}\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ]}c_{\rho }h \circ \sigma (z)\sigma ^{{\prime}}(z),\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in E.}$$
Let U be an open set that admits a complete local inverse, and
$$\displaystyle{B^{-1} \circ B(U) =\bigsqcup _{ j}\rho _{j}(U).}$$
Since
$$\tilde{S}$$
commutes with
$$\widetilde{M_{B}}$$
, by the theory of spectral decomposition,
$$\tilde{S}$$
also commutes with M
F , with
$$F =\chi _{B^{-1}\circ B(\Delta )}$$
for any measurable subsets
$$\Delta$$
of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
[DSZ, pp. 553–557]. In particular, letting
$$\Delta = U$$
, we have 5.33
$$\displaystyle{ \tilde{S}M_{\chi _{ B^{-1}\circ B(U)}} = M_{\chi _{ B^{-1}\circ B(U)}}\tilde{S}. }$$
As mentioned in the above paragraph, there is a sequence of polynomials {p
k } such that p
k converges to the characteristic function
$$f \triangleq \chi _{\rho _{i}(U)}$$
uniformly on the closure of B −1 ∘ B(U). Now by (5.33), we have
$$\displaystyle\begin{array}{rcl} \tilde{S}\chi _{B^{-1}\circ B(U)}p_{k}(z)& =& M_{\chi _{ B^{-1}\circ B(U)}}Sp_{k}(z) {}\\ & =& \sum _{[\rho ]}\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ]}\chi _{\sqcup \rho _{j}(U)}(z)c_{\rho }p_{k} \circ \sigma (z)\sigma ^{{\prime}}(z). {}\\ \end{array}$$

Letting k → ∞ gives that 5.34
$$\displaystyle{ \tilde{S}f =\sum _{[\rho ]}\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ]}c_{\rho }f \circ \sigma (z)\sigma ^{{\prime}}(z). }$$
By similar reasoning, if
$$f =\chi _{\rho _{i}(V )}$$
for some measurable subset V of U, (5.34) also holds. Thus, if f is a linear span of
$$\chi _{\rho _{i}(V )}(V \subseteq U)$$
, (5.34) holds. Therefore the identity (5.34) can be generalized to any f ∈ C
c (B −1 ∘ B(U)). That is, locally,
$$\tilde{S}$$
has the same representation as S.

By using the proof of Lemma 5.3.3 and (5.34), we deduce that
$$\displaystyle{(\tilde{S})^{{\ast}}f =\sum _{ [\rho ]}\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ^{-}]}\overline{c_{\rho }}f \circ \sigma (z)\sigma ^{{\prime}}(z),\ f \in C_{ c}(B^{-1} \circ B(U)).}$$
Write
$$\displaystyle{S^{{\ast}}h(z) =\sum _{ [\rho ]}\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ^{-}]}d_{\rho }h \circ \sigma (z)\sigma ^{{\prime}}(z),\ h \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in E,}$$
and similarly,
$$\displaystyle{\widetilde{S^{{\ast}}}f =\sum _{ [\rho ]}\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ^{-}]}d_{\rho }f \circ \sigma (z)\sigma ^{{\prime}}(z),\,f \in C_{ c}(B^{-1} \circ B(U)).}$$
Since
$$(\tilde{S})^{{\ast}} =\widetilde{ S^{{\ast}}}$$
, by the uniqueness of the coefficients c
ρ , we get
$$d_{\rho } = \overline{c_{\rho }}$$
for all ρ. Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{S^{{\ast}}h(z) =\sum _{ [\rho ]}\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ^{-}]}d_{\rho }h \circ \sigma (z)\sigma ^{{\prime}}(z) \equiv \sum _{ [\rho ]}\overline{c_{\rho }}\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ^{-}]}h(z),\ h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),\,z \in E.}$$
This gives the former part of Lemma 5.6.1. The remaining follows directly from Lemma 5.2.6. □

FormalPara.Heading: Remark 5.6.2
FormalPara.Para:
By further effort, one can show that (5.34) holds for any f in
$$C_{c}(\mathbb{D})$$
, a dense subspace of
$$L^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
.

Section1.Para:
Since Lemma 5.6.1 can be regarded as a substitute for Proposition 5.3.4 in some sense, the proof of Theorem 5.3.1 can be done as in Sect. 5.5 in Chap. 5
, and thus omitted.

The following example, as is well known, is presented to show that there exists a thin Blaschke product B satisfying
$$\overline{Z(B)} \supseteq \mathbb{T}.$$
See [GM1] and [CFT, Proposition 4.3
(i)], as well as [Ni, Chap. VII].

FormalPara.Heading: Example 5.6.3
FormalPara.Para:
First let us make an observation from [Hof1, p. 203, 204]: if {w
n } is a sequence in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
satisfying 5.35
$$\displaystyle{ \frac{1 -\vert w_{n}\vert } {1 -\vert w_{n-1}\vert } \leq c <1, }$$
then 5.36
$$\displaystyle{ \prod _{j:j\neq k}d(w_{k},w_{j}) \geq \big (\prod _{j=1}^{\infty }\frac{1 - c^{j}} {1 + c^{j}}\big)^{2}. }$$
Note that the right hand side tends to 1 as c tends to 0. The reasoning comes from [Hof1, p. 203, 204]. To show (5.36), note that
$$\displaystyle{\vert \frac{a - b} {1 -\overline{a}b}\vert \geq \frac{\vert \vert a\vert -\vert b\vert \vert } {1 -\vert a\vert \vert b\vert },\,a,b \in \mathbb{D}.}$$
Then 5.37
$$\displaystyle{ \prod _{j:j\neq k}d(w_{k},w_{j}) \geq \prod _{j:j<k}d(\vert w_{k}\vert,\vert w_{j}\vert )\prod _{j:j>k}d(\vert w_{k}\vert,\vert w_{j}\vert ). }$$
For j > k, by (5.35) 5.38
$$\displaystyle{ 1 -\vert w_{j}\vert \leq c^{j-k}(1 -\vert w_{ k}\vert ). }$$
and thus
$$\displaystyle{\vert w_{j}\vert -\vert w_{k}\vert \geq (1 - c^{j-k})(1 -\vert w_{ k}\vert ).}$$
Again by (5.38)
$$\displaystyle{1 -\vert w_{j}\vert \vert w_{k}\vert = (1 -\vert w_{k}\vert ) + (1 -\vert w_{j}\vert )\vert w_{k}\vert \leq (1 + c^{j-k})(1 -\vert w_{ k}\vert ).}$$
Therefore, for j > k,
$$\displaystyle{d(\vert w_{k}\vert,\vert w_{j}\vert ) = \frac{\vert w_{j}\vert -\vert w_{k}\vert } {1 -\vert w_{j}\vert \vert w_{k}\vert } \geq \frac{1 - c^{j-k}} {1 + c^{j-k}},}$$
and hence
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{j:j>k}d(\vert w_{k}\vert,\vert w_{j}\vert ) \geq \prod _{j=1}^{\infty }\frac{1 - c^{j}} {1 + c^{j}}.}$$
Similarly, we have
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{j:j<k}d(\vert w_{k}\vert,\vert w_{j}\vert ) \geq \prod _{j=1}^{\infty }\frac{1 - c^{j}} {1 + c^{j}},}$$
and then by (5.37) we get (5.36).

Let {c
n } be a sequence satisfying c
n > 0 and
$$\lim \limits _{n\rightarrow \infty }c_{n} = 0.$$
Suppose {z
n } is a sequence of points in the open unit disk
$$\mathbb{D}$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{ \frac{1 -\vert z_{n}\vert } {1 -\vert z_{n-1}\vert } = c_{n}.}$$
We will show that {z
n } is a thin Blaschke sequence. To see this, given a positive integer m, let k > m and consider the product 5.39
$$\displaystyle{ \prod _{j:j\neq k}d(z_{k},z_{j}) \equiv \prod _{1\leq j\leq m}d(z_{k},z_{j})\prod _{j>m,j\neq k}d(z_{k},z_{j}). }$$

Now write
$$\displaystyle{d_{m} =\sup \{ c_{j}: j \geq m\}.}$$
Since
$$\lim \limits _{n\rightarrow \infty }c_{n} = 0,$$
then
$$\lim \limits _{m\rightarrow \infty }d_{m} = 0.$$
For any k > m,
$$\displaystyle{ \frac{1 -\vert z_{k}\vert } {1 -\vert z_{k-1}\vert } = c_{k} \leq d_{m},}$$
and thus
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{j>m,j\neq k}d(z_{k},z_{j}) \geq \big (\prod _{j=1}^{\infty }\frac{1 - d_{m}^{j}} {1 + d_{m}^{j}}\big)^{2},\,k> m,}$$
which implies that
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{j>m,j\neq k}d(z_{k},z_{j})}$$
tends to 1 as m → ∞. For any
$$\varepsilon> 0$$
, there is an m 0 such that
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{j>m_{0},j\neq k}d(z_{k},z_{j}) \geq 1 -\varepsilon.}$$
On the other hand,
$$\displaystyle{\lim \limits _{k\rightarrow \infty }\prod _{1\leq j\leq m_{0}}d(z_{k},z_{j}) = 1,}$$
which, combined with (5.39), implies that
$$\displaystyle{\liminf _{k\rightarrow \infty }\prod _{j:j\neq k}d(z_{k},z_{j}) \geq 1 -\varepsilon.}$$
Therefore, by the arbitrariness of
$$\varepsilon$$
,
$$\displaystyle{\lim _{k\rightarrow \infty }\prod _{j:j\neq k}d(z_{k},z_{j}) = 1,}$$
which implies that {z
k } is a thin Blaschke product.

Now choose a dense sequence {r
n } in [0, 1]. If {z
n } is given as above, then { | z
n | exp(2π i r
n )} also gives a thin Blaschke sequence. Moreover, we have
$$\displaystyle{\overline{\{\vert z_{n}\vert \exp (2\pi ir_{n})\}} \supseteq \mathbb{T}.}$$
For example, {z
n } is a thin Blaschk sequence if we require that
$$\vert z_{n}\vert = 1 - \frac{1} {n!}.$$

Section1.Heading:
Abelian
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
for Thin Blaschke Products
Section1.Para:
It is known that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi )$$
are abelian for finite Blaschke products ϕ, see Theorem 4.2.1
. This result can be nontrivially generalized to the class of thin Blaschke products, which is the main result in this section, due to Guo and Huang [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: For any thin Blaschke product B,

Section1.Para:
Section 5.6 in this chapter has provided a complete geometric characterization for when
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is nontrivial. This section will present the structure of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
, as follows [GH4]. For the case of finite Blaschke products, see [DSZ, Theorem 7.6].

Para.Emphasis: If B is a thin Blaschke product, then the von Neumann algebra

Section1.Para:
Recall that for each local inverse ρ, G[ρ] is the graph of [ρ]. Therefore, the dimension of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
equals the number of all finite components G[ρ] of S
B . Also, note that Theorem 5.3.1 can be regarded as a direct consequence of Theorem 5.7.2. If B is a finite Blaschke product, each component of S
B is necessarily finite, and thus the dimension of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
equals the number of components of S
B [DSZ, DPW].
Before giving the proofs of Theorems 5.7.1 and 5.7.2, we establish the following lemma.

Para.Emphasis: For any thin Blaschke product B, all operators S
mutually commutes, where [σ] runs over components of S

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para: The proof essentially comes from [GH4].

Observe that for any [σ] and [τ],
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\sigma ]}\mathcal{E}_{[\tau ]}$$
has the form
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{i}\mathcal{E}_{[\sigma _{i}]},}$$
where the sum is finite and some σ
i may lie in the same class. Moreover, Lemma 5.2.6 and Proposition 5.3.4 tells us that each σ
i satisfying ♯[σ
i ] < ∞ and ♯[σ
i
−] < ∞. Based on this observation, we define the composition
$$\displaystyle{[\tau ] \circ [\sigma ]}$$
to be a formal sum ∑
i [σ
i ]; and its graph G([τ] ∘ [σ]) is defined to be the disjoint union of the graphs G[σ
i ], denoted by ∑
i
G[σ
i ]. For example, if both σ and τ are in
$$\mathrm{Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
, then G([τ] ∘ [σ]) = G([τ ∘σ]).

Clearly,
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\sigma ]}\mathcal{E}_{[\tau ]} = \mathcal{E}_{[\tau ]}\mathcal{E}_{[\sigma ]}$$
if and only if
$$[\sigma ] \circ [\tau ] = [\tau ] \circ [\sigma ]$$
; if and only if G([σ] ∘ [τ]) = G([τ] ∘ [σ]). Let us take a close look at G([σ] ∘ [τ]) and G([τ] ∘ [σ]). Write m = ♯[σ] and n = ♯[τ]. Fix a point z 0 ∈ E, there are exactly m points with the form (z 0, ⋅ ) in G[σ]:
$$\displaystyle{(z_{0},\xi _{1}^{{\prime}}),\cdots \,,(z_{ 0},\xi _{m}^{{\prime}}).}$$
For each j = 1, ⋯ , m, there are n points with the form (ξ
j
′ , ⋅ ) in G[τ]:
$$\displaystyle{(\xi _{j}^{{\prime}},\xi _{ j}^{k}),\ k = 1,\cdots \,,n.}$$
For each j and k, (z 0, ξ
j
k ) is in some G[σ
i ] where [σ
i ] appears in the sum of [τ] ∘ [σ]. By omitting the order of (z 0, ξ
j
k ), the sequence {(z 0, ξ
j
k )} j, k represents G([τ] ∘ [σ]). Similarly, there are exactly n points with the form (z 0, ⋅ ) in G[τ]:
$$\displaystyle{(z_{0},\eta _{1}^{{\prime}}),\cdots \,,(z_{ 0},\eta _{n}^{{\prime}}).}$$
For each j = 1, ⋯ , n, there are m points with the form (η
j
′ , ⋅ ) in G[σ]:
$$\displaystyle{(\eta _{j}^{{\prime}},\eta _{ j}^{k}),\ k = 1,\cdots \,,m.}$$
Also, the sequence {(z 0, η
j
k )} j, k represents G([σ] ∘ [τ]). Then
$$\displaystyle{G([\sigma ] \circ [\tau ]) = G([\tau ] \circ [\sigma ])}$$
if and only if the sequences
$$\{(z_{0},\xi _{j}^{k})\}_{j,k}$$
and {(z 0, η
j
k )} j, k are equal, omitting the order. For example, the sequences
$$\displaystyle{(z_{0},z_{0}),(z_{0},\rho (z_{0})),(z_{0},z_{0}),(z_{0},\rho (z_{0}))}$$
and
$$\displaystyle{(z_{0},z_{0}),(z_{0},z_{0}),(z_{0},\rho (z_{0})),(z_{0},\rho (z_{0}))}$$

are equal if we omit the order, but they are never equal to the following sequence
$$\displaystyle{(z_{0},z_{0}),(z_{0},\rho (z_{0})).}$$

Below, to finish the proof, we need some geometry of thin Blaschke products. As done in the proof of Proposition 5.3.4, let
$$\Omega _{t}$$
be a simply-connected domain whose boundary is an analytic Jordan curve; and
$$\Omega _{t}$$
is B-glued. Also, we may assume that t is enough large such that z 0 and all finitely many points
$$\xi _{j}^{{\prime}},\xi _{j}^{k};\eta _{j}^{{\prime}},\eta _{j}^{k}$$
lie in
$$\Omega _{t}$$
. Again by the proof of Proposition 5.3.4, there is a biholomorphic map
$$f: \mathbb{D} \rightarrow \Omega _{t}$$
such that B ∘ f = t ϕ for some finite Blaschke product. The equivalent classes [σ] and [τ] naturally grow on
$$\Omega _{t}$$
, and the compositions [τ] ∘ [σ] and [σ] ∘ [τ] also make sense on
$$\Omega _{t}$$
. By the identity B ∘ f = t ϕ, the map
$$\displaystyle{[\rho ]\mapsto [\rho ^{{\ast}}] \triangleq [f^{-1} \circ \rho \circ f]}$$
maps each component
$$[\rho ] \in \mathcal{E}_{B\vert _{\Omega _{ t}}}$$
to
$$[\rho ^{{\ast}}] \in \mathcal{E}_{\phi }$$
. Special attention should be paid to ρ = σ or τ. By the proof of Theorem 4.2.1
,
$$\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}_{[\sigma ^{{\ast}}]}\mathcal{E}_{[\tau ^{{\ast}}]} = \mathcal{E}_{[\tau ^{{\ast}}]}\mathcal{E}_{[\sigma ^{{\ast}}]},}$$
which implies that
$$\displaystyle{G([\sigma ^{{\ast}}] \circ [\tau ^{{\ast}}]) = G([\tau ^{{\ast}}] \circ [\sigma ^{{\ast}}]).}$$
This immediately gives that
$$G([\sigma ] \circ [\tau ]) = G([\tau ] \circ [\sigma ])$$
, and hence
$$\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}_{[\sigma ]}\mathcal{E}_{[\tau ]} = \mathcal{E}_{[\tau ]}\mathcal{E}_{[\sigma ]}.}$$
The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para:
In some sense, a finite Blaschke product can be regarded as a thin Blaschke product, but with finite zeros. It is of interest that the commutativity of the von Neumann algebras
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
for thin Blaschke products B is connected with that of finite Blaschke products, by the following [DSZ, GH4].

Para.Emphasis: For any thin Blaschke product B with
For any finite Blaschke product ϕ,
For any finite Blaschke product ϕ, M
has exactly q minimal reducing subspaces, where q denotes the number of components of S

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
First, we show (3) ⇒ (2). Given a finite Blaschke product ϕ, let q denote the number of components of S
ϕ . Clearly, q ≤ order ϕ < ∞. By assumption, M
ϕ has exactly q minimal reducing subspaces, which implies that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi )$$
has exactly q minimal projections because
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi ) <\infty$$
, see Corollary 4.2.4
. Then by Proposition 2.6.8
,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi )$$
is abelian.

To see (2) ⇒ (3), assume that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi )$$
is abelian, where ϕ is a finite Blaschke product. By [DSZ, Theorem 7.6],
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi ) = q,$$
where q denotes the number of components of S
ϕ . Then applying Theorem 2.5.11
shows that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi )$$
is generated by mutually orthogonal minimal projections, whose number equals q. That is, M
ϕ has exactly q minimal reducing subspaces.

To prove (1) ⇒ (2), consider the thin Blaschke product ψ whose zero sequence is
$$\{1 - \frac{1} {n!}\}$$
, see Example 5.6.3. For a fixed finite Blaschke product ϕ, write
$$B \triangleq \psi \circ \phi$$
. By Example 5.3.5, B is also a thin Blaschke product and it is clear that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) \supseteq \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi )$$
. Since
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is abelian, then so is
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi )$$
.

It remains to show that (2) ⇒ (1). Suppose B is a thin Blaschke product. By Theorem 5.7.2,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is generated by S [ρ], where G[ρ] has finite multiplicity (and hence by Proposition 5.3.4 G[ρ] has bi-finite multiplicities). Therefore, Lemma 5.7.3 shows that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is abelian. □

Section1.Para:
By Theorem 4.2.1
,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(\phi )$$
is abelian for any finite Blaschke product ϕ. Therefore, for any thin Blaschke product B with
$$\overline{Z(B)} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}$$
,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is abelian. In general, one can provide a proof of Theorem 5.7.1 as follows, which essentially comes from [GH4].

FormalPara.Heading: Proof of Theorem 5.7.1
FormalPara.Para:
Suppose B is a thin Blaschke product. For any
$$S,T \in \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
, write 5.40
$$\displaystyle{ S =\sum c_{\rho }\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad T =\sum d_{\rho }\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}. }$$
Let S
m and T
n denote the corresponding partial sum of the expanding series (5.40) for S and T, respectively. By Lemma 5.7.3, for any two local inverse ρ and σ,
$$\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}\mathcal{E}_{[\sigma ]} = \mathcal{E}_{[\sigma ]}\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}.}$$
Then we have
$$\displaystyle{T_{m}S_{n}h = S_{n}T_{m}h,h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}).}$$

Section1.Para:
Letting n tend to ∞, both sides converge to holomorphic functions on compact subsets of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. That is, 5.41
$$\displaystyle{ T_{m}Sh = ST_{m}h,h \in L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}). }$$
As m tends to infinity, the left-hand side of (5.41) converges to TSh uniformly on compact sets. Now consider h = K
λ with λ ∈ E. We claim that: 5.42
$$\displaystyle{ \lim _{m\rightarrow \infty }\|T_{m}K_{\lambda } - TK_{\lambda }\| = 0. }$$
If (5.42) is proved, then the right-hand side of (5.41) converges in norm (and hence converges uniformly on compact sets) to K
λ . Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{TSK_{\lambda } = STK_{\lambda },\ \ \lambda \in E.}$$
That is, [S, T]K
λ = 0, λ ∈ E, where
$$\displaystyle{[S,T] \triangleq ST - TS.}$$
Since span{K
λ : λ ∈ E} is dense in
$$L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
, [S, T] = 0, completing the proof.

Now it remains to show (5.42). First, observe that for each ρ with ♯[ρ] < ∞,
$$\displaystyle{\langle \mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}K_{\lambda },f\rangle =\langle K_{\lambda },\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}^{{\ast}}f\rangle,f \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}),}$$
which, combined with Lemma 5.3.3, gives that 5.43
$$\displaystyle{ \mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}K_{\lambda } =\sum _{\sigma \in [\rho ^{-}]}\overline{\sigma (\lambda )^{{\prime}}}K_{\sigma (\lambda )}. }$$
Now rewrite
$$\displaystyle{T =\sum d_{\rho }^{{\prime}}\mathcal{E}_{ [\rho ^{-}]} \equiv \sum d_{\rho }^{{\prime}}\mathcal{E}_{ [\rho ]}^{{\ast}}.}$$
On a neighborhood V of λ, all local inverses of B can be written as {ρ
k } and rewrite d
k

$$d_{\rho _{k}}^{{\prime}}.$$
We have
$$\displaystyle{Th(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }d_{ k}^{{\prime}}h \circ \rho _{ k}(z)\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z),z \in V.}$$
This, combined with (5.43), yields that
$$\displaystyle{TK_{\lambda }(z) =\sum _{ k=0}^{\infty }d_{ k}^{{\prime}}\overline{\rho _{ k}^{{\prime}}(z)}K_{\rho _{ k}(\lambda )}(z),z \in V.}$$
Below, we will show that
$$\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }d_{k}^{{\prime}}\overline{\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)}K_{\rho _{k}(\lambda )}$$
converges in norm, which immediately shows that
$$\displaystyle{\lim _{m\rightarrow \infty }\|T_{m}K_{\lambda } - TK_{\lambda }\| = 0,}$$
as desired, because {S
m
K

∞ is a subsequence of the partial sums
$$\{\sum _{k=0}^{n}d_{k}^{{\prime}}\overline{\rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(z)}K_{\rho _{k}(\lambda )}\}_{n=1}^{\infty }$$
.

In fact, B ∘ρ
k = B holds on V for k = 0, 1, ⋯ , which gives that 5.44
$$\displaystyle{ \vert B^{{\prime}}(\rho _{ k}(\lambda ))\vert \vert \rho _{k}^{{\prime}}(\lambda )\vert = \vert B^{{\prime}}(\lambda )\vert. }$$
Write a = B(λ), by Proposition 5.1.4 φ
a (B) is a thin Blaschke product whose zero sequence is {ρ
k (λ)}. Then there is a numerical constant δ > 0 such that
$$\displaystyle{\prod _{j,j\neq k}d(\rho _{j}(\lambda ),\rho _{k}(\lambda )) \geq \delta,}$$
and then by computations
$$\displaystyle{\vert (\varphi _{a} \circ B)^{{\prime}}(\rho _{ k}(\lambda ))\vert = \frac{1} {1 -\vert \rho _{k}(\lambda )\vert ^{2}}\prod _{j,j\neq k}d(\rho _{j}(\lambda ),\rho _{k}(\lambda )) \geq \delta \frac{1} {1 -\vert \rho _{k}(\lambda )\vert ^{2}}.}$$
Since
$$B(\rho _{k}(\lambda )) = B(\lambda ) = a$$
, the above immediately shows that
$$\displaystyle{ \frac{1} {1 -\vert \rho _{k}(\lambda )\vert ^{2}} \geq \vert \varphi _{a}^{{\prime}}(a)\vert \vert B^{{\prime}}(\rho _{ k}(\lambda ))\vert \geq \delta \frac{1} {1 -\vert \rho _{k}(\lambda )\vert ^{2}},}$$
and hence
$$\displaystyle{ \frac{1} {\vert \varphi _{a}^{{\prime}}(a)\vert } \frac{1} {1 -\vert \rho _{k}(\lambda )\vert ^{2}} \geq \vert B^{{\prime}}(\rho _{ k}(\lambda ))\vert \geq \frac{\delta } {\vert \varphi _{a}^{{\prime}}(a)\vert } \frac{1} {1 -\vert \rho _{k}(\lambda )\vert ^{2}}.}$$
Then by (5.44), there is a positive constant C such that 5.45

On the other hand, φ

Then by (5.45),

FormalPara.Heading: Remark 5.7.5
FormalPara.Para:
By the proof of Theorem 5.7.1, Lemma 5.6.1 still holds even if the condition
$$\overline{Z(B)} \not\supseteq \mathbb{T}$$
is dropped.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof of Theorem 5.7.2
FormalPara.Para: The proof comes essentially from [GH4].

Suppose B is a thin Blaschke product. We must show that the von Neumann algebra
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is generated by all
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
, where
$$\sharp [\rho ]\,<\,\infty$$
. By von Neumann bicommutant theorem, it is enough to show that the commutant of
$$span\,\{\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}\}$$
equals that of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
. To see this, for a given operator A commuting with all
$$\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]}$$
, we must show that A commutes with each operator in
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
.

Let V be a disk centered at 0, and write
$$\hat{V } = V \cap E$$
. By the proof of Theorem 5.7.1, for any
$$T \in \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
there is a sequence {T
N } in
$$span\ \{\mathcal{E}_{[\rho ]};\sharp [\rho ] <\infty \}$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{T_{N}K_{z} \rightarrow TK_{z}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad T_{N}^{{\ast}}K_{ z} \rightarrow T^{{\ast}}K_{ z},\ \ z \in \hat{ V },}$$
where both convergence are in norm. Note that A commutes with T
N , and hence
$$\displaystyle{\langle AT_{N}K_{z},K_{z}\rangle =\langle AK_{z},T_{N}^{{\ast}}K_{ z}\rangle,\,z \in V.}$$
Since
$$\hat{V }$$
is dense in V, then by the continuity of Berezin transformation, we have 5.46
$$\displaystyle{ \langle AT_{N}K_{z},K_{z}\rangle =\langle AK_{z},T_{N}^{{\ast}}K_{ z}\rangle,\,z \in V. }$$
Take limits in (5.46) and we get
$$\displaystyle{\langle ATK_{z},K_{z}\rangle =\langle AK_{z},T^{{\ast}}K_{ z}\rangle =\langle TAK_{z},K_{z}\rangle.}$$
The property of Berezin transformation yields that AT = TA. The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para: The proof of Theorem 5.7.2 can be translated to the case of finite Blaschke products, with some simplification possibly.

Section1.Heading: Finite Blaschke Product Revisited
Section1.Para:
In this section, we will turn back to finite Blaschke products, which will be treated with the techniques developed in this chapter. Below, B denotes a finite Blaschke product, and some examples of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
will be provided. As we will see, in some cases the dimension
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is calculated.

The following shows that even if the assumption of Corollary 5.4.10 fails,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
may be also two-dimensional. In fact, it is a consequence of the proof of Lemma 5.5.1, see [GH4].

Para.Emphasis: Suppose B is a finite Blaschke product. Then there is ans(0 < s < 1) such that for any

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
By the proof of Lemma 5.5.1, there are two disjoint sub-domains
$$\Omega _{1}$$
and
$$\Omega _{2}$$
of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
, which are components of
$$\{z \in \mathbb{D}: \vert B(z)\vert <t\}$$
for some t > 0. For some
$$w \in \Omega _{2} \cap E$$
, there are n different points in
$$\Omega _{1}$$
: w 1, ⋯ , w
n , satisfying
$$\displaystyle{B(w_{j}) = B(w),j = 1,\cdots \,,n.}$$
Since
$$\Omega _{1}$$
is B-glued and
$$B\vert _{\Omega _{2}}$$
is univalent, by applying Lemma 5.4.8 one can show that
$$\displaystyle{G[(w,w_{1})] = G[(w,w_{j})],j = 2,\cdots \,,n.}$$
Thus,
$$G[(w,w_{1})]$$
and the trivial component G[(w, w)] are the only components of S
B , and hence by a similar version of Theorem 5.7.2,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is generated by
$$S_{[(w,w_{1})]}$$
and I. Therefore,
$$\displaystyle{\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B\varphi _{\lambda }) = 2.}$$
By Theorem 2.5.11
a finite dimensional von Neumann algebra is ∗-isomorphic to the direct sum
$$\bigoplus _{k=1}^{r}M_{n_{k}}(\mathbb{C})$$
of full matrix algebras, and then
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B\varphi _{\lambda })$$
is ∗-isomorphic to
$$\mathbb{C} \oplus \mathbb{C}$$
. Thus,
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B\varphi _{\lambda })$$
is abelian. □

Section1.Para:
The following provides more examples of von Neumann algebras
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
[GH4].

FormalPara.Heading: Example 5.8.2
FormalPara.Para:
Let a 1, a 2, a 3 be three different points in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
and a 1 a 2 a 3 ≠ 0. Write
$$\displaystyle{B = z\varphi _{a_{1}}^{m}(z)\varphi _{ a_{2}}^{n}(z)\varphi _{ a_{3}}^{l}(z).}$$
Pick a point z 0 that is enough close to 0. By Theorem 2.1.13
, it is not difficult to see that there are
$$m + n + l + 1$$
points in B −1(B(z 0)):
$$\displaystyle{z_{0};z_{1}^{1},\cdots \,,z_{ 1}^{m};z_{ 2}^{1},\cdots \,,z_{ 2}^{n};z_{ 3}^{1},\cdots \,,z_{ 3}^{l},}$$
where z
i
j are around a
i (i = 1, 2, 3) for all possible j. Then by the proof of Lemma 5.4.8, we have
$$\displaystyle{G[(z_{0},z_{i}^{1})] = G[(z_{ 0},z_{i}^{j})],\,i = 1,2,3,\,j = 1,2,\cdots \,.}$$
Thus, there are at most four components of S
B :
$$\displaystyle{G[(z_{0},z_{0})] \equiv G[z],G[(z_{0},z_{1}^{1})],G[(z_{ 0},z_{2}^{1})]\ \mathrm{and}\ G[(z_{ 0},z_{3}^{1})].}$$
By [DSZ, Theorem 7.6] or the comments below Theorem 5.7.2,
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) \leq 4,$$
and hence
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is abelian. Similarly, if
$$B = z^{n}\varphi _{a_{1}}(z)$$
, then
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) = 2$$
. In this case, M
B has exactly 2 minimal reducing subspaces. In particular, if n = 3, this is exactly [SZZ1, Theorem 3.1
].

To provide more examples of

Section1.Para:
All discussions below are based on the fact that
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
equals the number of the components of S
B for a finite Blaschke product B. The following example is provided by Guo and Huang.

FormalPara.Heading: Example 5.8.4
FormalPara.Para:
Let
$$B =\varphi _{ a}^{m}\varphi _{b}^{n}$$
be a finite Blaschke product, where a and b are different points in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
and gcd(m, n) = 1. Then
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) = 2$$
; equivalently, S
B has exactly two components. We only deal with the case where m > 1 and n > 1.

By Bochner’s Theorem, B has
$$m + n - 1$$
critical points, counting multiplicity. Since both a and b are critical points with multiplicity m − 1 and n − 1, respectively, and
$$m + n - 1 - (m - 1) - (n - 1) = 1,$$
then there is exactly one critical point w different from a and b such that
$$\displaystyle{B^{{\prime}}(w) = 0\quad \mathrm{and}\quad B^{{\prime\prime}}(w)\neq 0.}$$
Pick an enough small positive number
$$\varepsilon$$
with
$$\varepsilon <\vert B(w)\vert$$
. By Rouche’s theorem and Theorem 2.1.13
, there is a small disk around a containing a 1, ⋯ , a
m , and another disk around b containing b 1, ⋯ , b
n (both sequences {a
i } and {b
j } are in anti-clockwise direction), where a
i and b
j are in
$$B^{-1}(\varepsilon \mathbb{D})$$
.

Now we can draw a curve L connecting
$$\varepsilon$$
and w, such that
$$\displaystyle{L \subseteq \big (\vert B(w)\vert \mathbb{D} \cap E\big).}$$
Then B −1(L) consisting of the following curves:
$$\displaystyle{\sigma _{1},\sigma _{2},\cdots \,,\sigma _{m};\gamma _{1},\gamma _{2},\cdots \,,\gamma _{n},}$$
where a
i ∈ σ
i and b
j ∈ γ
j for all i and j. Without loss of generality, assume that σ 1 ∩γ 1 = { w} and σ
i ∩γ
j = ∅ for (i, j) ≠ (1, 1), see Fig. 5.8.
Fig. 5.8
B −1(L)

Take a local inverse ρ such that ρ(b 2) = b 1. Clearly, G[ρ] ≠ G[z]. Sinceσ 1 ∩γ 1 = { w}, B
′ (w) = 0 and B
′ (γ 2(1)) ≠ 0, then by Lemma 5.4.8
$$\displaystyle{G[(b_{2},a_{1})] = G[(b_{2},b_{1})].}$$
Since gcd(m, n) = 1, then by a careful verification, the proof of Lemma 5.4.8 shows that
$$\displaystyle{G[(b_{2},a_{j})] = G[(b_{2},b_{1})],\quad j = 1,\cdots \,,n.}$$
Thus G[ρ] contains these points:
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{1});({\ast},a_{1}),({\ast},a_{2}),\cdots \,,({\ast},a_{m})\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = b_{2}.}$$
Replace b 2 with b 1 in the above sequence. Along with a rotation from b 2 to b 1 (see the proof of Lemma 5.4.8), applying the techniques of analytic continuation shows that G[ρ] containing the follows:
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{n});({\ast},a_{m}),({\ast},a_{1})\cdots \,,({\ast},a_{m-1})\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = b_{1},}$$
or
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{n});({\ast},a_{1}),\cdots \,,({\ast},a_{m})\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = b_{1}.}$$

Note that the map
$$\big(\sigma _{1}\sharp \gamma _{1}\big)(t) \rightarrow \big (\gamma _{1}\sharp \sigma _{1}\big)(t)$$
naturally induces a local inverse exchanging a 1 with b 1, and thus G[ρ] contains the point sequence:
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{n});({\ast},b_{1}),({\ast},a_{2})\cdots \,,({\ast},a_{m})\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = a_{1}.}$$
Since gcd(m, n) = 1 and (a 1, b 1) ∈ G[ρ], then by Lemma 5.8.3 all points (a 1, b
j )(1 ≤ j ≤ n) lie in G[ρ]. Therefore, G[ρ] contains the following
$$m + n - 1$$
points:
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{1}),\cdots \,,({\ast},b_{n});({\ast},a_{2})\cdots \,,({\ast},a_{m})\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = a_{1},}$$
which shows that
$$\sharp [\rho ] \geq m + n - 1$$
. On the other hand,
$$\displaystyle{\sum \sharp [\sigma ] =\mathrm{ order}\,B = m + n,}$$
and then
$$\sharp [\rho ] \leq m + n - \sharp [z] = m + n - 1$$
, forcing
$$\sharp [\rho ] = m + n - 1$$
. Therefore, [ρ] and [z] are all the components of S
B .

Section1.Para: In general, we have the following result due to Guo and Huang.

FormalPara.Heading: Proposition 5.8.5
FormalPara.Para:
For two different points
$$a,b \in \mathbb{D}$$
, put B = φ a m φ b n , where gcd (m,n) = d. Then S B has exactly d + 1 components, and thus
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) = d + 1.$$

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
By Example 5.8.4, we assume that gcd(m, n) = d > 1, and it suffices to show that S
B has exactly d + 1 components. Rewrite
$$\displaystyle{m = kd,n = ld\quad \mathrm{with}\,\gcd (k,l) = 1.}$$
Suppose a
i , σ
i and b
j , γ
j (1 ≤ i ≤ m, 1 ≤ j ≤ n) are the same as in Example 5.8.4, also see Fig. 5.8. For convenience, for any
$$p,q \in \mathbb{Z}_{+},$$
we write a [p] for
$$a_{p^{{\prime}}}$$
with
$$p = p^{{\prime}}\mod m$$
, and b [q] for
$$b_{q^{{\prime\prime}}}$$
with
$$q = q^{{\prime\prime}}\mod n$$
.

Now take a local inverse ρ such that ρ(b 2) = b 1. Clearly, [ρ] ≠ [z]. Then by Lemma 5.4.8,
$$\displaystyle{G[(b_{2},a_{1})] = G[(b_{2},b_{1})].}$$
Since
$$\gcd (m,n) = d$$
, by a similar version of Lemma 5.8.3
$$\displaystyle{G[(b_{2},a_{1})] = G[(b_{2},a_{[1+pd]})],p = 0,1,\cdots \,.}$$
Therefore, G[ρ] contains the following
$$\displaystyle{(b_{2},b_{1});(b_{2},a_{[1+pd]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,}$$

and by the techniques of analytic continuation, G[ρ] also contains
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{n});({\ast},a_{[pd]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = b_{1},}$$
and
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{n});({\ast},a_{[pd]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = a_{1}.}$$
Thus, (a 1, b
n ) ∈ G[ρ], then applying the techniques of analytic continuation shows that G[ρ] also contains (a 1, b [pd]) for p = 0, 1, ⋯ . Therefore, G[ρ] contains the following:
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},a_{[pd]});({\ast},b_{[pd]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = a_{1},}$$
By a bit more effort, one can show that G[ρ] contains the following:
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},a_{[pd+i-1]});({\ast},b_{[pd+i-1]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = a_{i},}$$
and
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},a_{[pd+j-1]});({\ast},b_{[pd+j-1]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = b_{j},}$$
for any a
i and b
j . Moreover, this sequence is complete; that is, if (z, w) ∈ G[ρ] with z = a
i (or z = b
j ), then (z, w) must lie in the above sequence. This immediately gives that
$$\displaystyle{\sharp G[\rho ] = k + l.}$$
Also, by a similar discussion, one can show for
$$t = 1,\cdots \,,d - 1,$$
some component G[ρ
t ] contains the following points:
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},a_{[pd+i+t]});({\ast},b_{[pd+i+t]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = a_{i},}$$
and
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},a_{[pd+j+t]});({\ast},b_{[pd+j+t]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = b_{j}.}$$
We have
$$\sharp G[\rho _{t}] = k + l,$$
and G[ρ
t ] differs for distinct t. In particular, for
$$t = d - 1$$
,
$$G[\rho _{d-1}] = G[\rho ].$$
There exists one additional component, say G[ρ
d ], that contains the following:
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{[pd+1]});({\ast},a_{[pd+1]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = a_{1}\quad \mathrm{excluding}(a_{1},a_{1}),}$$
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{[pd+i]});({\ast},a_{[pd+i]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = a_{i}\quad \mathrm{excluding}(a_{i},a_{i}),}$$
and
$$\displaystyle{({\ast},b_{[pd+j]});({\ast},a_{[pd+j]}),p = 0,1,\cdots \,,\quad \mathrm{with}\quad {\ast} = b_{j}\quad \mathrm{excluding}(b_{j},b_{j}).}$$
Note that
$$\sharp G[\rho _{d}] = k + l - 1$$
, and then
$$\displaystyle{\sum _{t=1}^{d}\sharp G[\rho _{ t}] + \sharp G[z] = (k + l)(d - 1) + (k + l - 1) + 1 = (k + l)d =\mathrm{ order}\,\,B.}$$
Therefore, all
$$G[\rho _{t}](1 \leq t \leq d)$$
and the identity component are all components of S
B . The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para:
Some words are in order. In the proof of Proposition 5.8.5, we mention the notion of “complete”. A finite sequence {(z 0, w
j ): j = 0, ⋯ , k} is called complete if G[(z 0, w
j )] = G[(z 0, w 0)], and whenever (z 0, w) ∈ G[(z 0, w 0)], w must lie in {w
j : j = 0, ⋯ , k}. For a given sequence {(z 0, w
j ): j = 0, ⋯ , k}, it is complete if and only if {w
j : j = 0, ⋯ , k} equals the set of all
$$\tilde{\rho }(z_{0})$$
, where ρ is the local inverse satisfying ρ(z 0) = w 0, and
$$\tilde{\rho }$$
is the analytic continuation of ρ along any possible loop γ at z 0. By the theory of algebraic topology, the value
$$\tilde{\rho }(z_{0})$$
is invariant under the homotopy equivalence of γ. Thus, the loop γ can be chosen as the product of finitely many simple loops σ
j at z 0, with each winding along exactly one point in B −1 ∘ B(Z(B
′ )) at most once. This simplification would make our job easier, which has been done in the proof of Proposition 5.8.5. By careful verification, one sees that those mentioned sequences in the proof of Proposition 5.8.5 are complete.
Furthermore, by the same methods one can compute the following example, provided by Guo and Huang. The details are omitted.

FormalPara.Heading: Example 5.8.6
FormalPara.Para:
For three different points
$$a_{1},a_{2},a_{3} \in \mathbb{D}$$
,
$$B =\varphi _{ a_{1}}^{m}\varphi _{a_{2}}^{n}\varphi _{a_{3}}^{k}$$
where gcd(m, n, k) = 1. We assume that there is at most one additional critical point of B except for a 1, a 2 and a 3. If min(m, n, k) ≥ 2, then S
B has exactly two components. If m = n and k = 1, then S
B has exactly three components.

Section1.Para:
To end this section, we will give another approach for the structures of
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
where order B = 3 and 4.

As done in [GSZZ, DPW], two finite Blaschke products B 1 and B 2 are called similar if there are two members
$$m_{1},m_{2} \in \mathrm{ Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{B_{2} = m_{1} \circ B_{1} \circ m_{2}.}$$
In this case, we write B 1 ∼ B 2. If so, then there is a unitarily isomorphism between the von Neumann algebras
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B_{1})$$
and
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B_{2})$$
, which is complemented by the unitary operator
$$\displaystyle{U_{m_{2}}: f \rightarrow f \circ m_{2}m_{2}^{{\prime}},\,f \in L_{ a}^{2}(\mathbb{D}).}$$
The following was shown in [GSZZ, Theorem 4].

Para.Emphasis: Suppose B is a finite Blaschke product of order 3. If B ∼ z
. Otherwise, there is a nonzero point

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Suppose B is a finite Blaschke product of order 3. Then by Bochner’s theorem (Theorem 5.4.6), B has 2 critical points, counting multiplicity. Assume that z 0 is one of the critical points, and write b = B(z 0). Then it is not difficult to see that
$$\varphi _{b} \circ B \circ \varphi _{z_{0}}$$
has a zero at 0, whose order is ≥ 2. Thus, we have either B ∼ z 3 or B ∼ z 2 φ
λ for some
$$\lambda \in \mathbb{D} -\{ 0\}$$
. Form the discussion below Example 5.8.6, it suffices to consider two cases: B = z 3 and B = z 2 φ
λ .

If B = z 3, define
$$\rho _{j}(z) = e^{\frac{2ji\pi } {3} }z(j = 0,1,2)$$
, and then ρ 0, ρ 1 and ρ 2 are three local inverses of B, belonging to
$$\mathrm{Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
. This shows that S
B has three components
$$\displaystyle{\{(z,\rho _{j}(z)): z \in \mathbb{D},z\neq 0\}(0 \leq j \leq 2),}$$
and hence
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) = 3.$$
Otherwise,
$$B \sim z^{2}\varphi _{\lambda }$$
with λ ≠ 0. By Example 5.8.2, S
B has exactly two components, and thus
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) = 2.$$
The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para:
It should be pointed out that B ∼ z 3 if and only if
$$B = c\varphi _{a}(\varphi _{\lambda }^{3})$$
for some
$$\lambda,a \in \mathbb{D}$$
and | c | = 1.
The following context focuses on the case of order B = 4. First we need a lemma.

Para.Emphasis: Let B be a finite Blaschke product. Then B ∼ z
for some b ≠ 0 if and only if there is some

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
First assume that B is a finite Blaschke product such that
$$\displaystyle{B \sim z^{2}\varphi _{ b}^{2},}$$
where b ≠ 0. Put h = z φ
b . Since
$$z^{2}\varphi _{b}^{2} = (z\varphi _{b})^{2}$$
, we have B ∼ z 2 ∘ h. Since h ∼ z 2, it is easy to see there is a nonzero
$$c \in \mathbb{D}$$
such that B ∼ φ
c
2(z 2). Consider
$$\varphi _{c^{2}} \circ \varphi _{c}^{2}(z^{2})$$
. There is some λ ≠ 0 in
$$\mathbb{D}$$
and some unimodular constant ξ such that
$$\varphi _{c^{2}} \circ \varphi _{c}^{2} =\xi z\varphi _{\lambda ^{2}},$$
forcing
$$\displaystyle{\varphi _{c^{2}} \circ \varphi _{c}^{2}(z^{2}) =\xi z^{2}\varphi _{ \lambda ^{2}}(z^{2}).}$$
Then
$$B \sim z^{2}\varphi _{\lambda ^{2}}(z^{2}).$$

Conversely, assume that there is a constant λ ≠ 0 satisfying
$$\displaystyle{B \sim z^{2}\varphi _{ \lambda ^{2}}(z^{2}).}$$
Write
$$B_{1} = z\varphi _{\lambda ^{2}}$$
, and B ∼ B 1(z 2). Since B 1 ∼ z 2, there is some constant a ≠ 0 such that
$$\displaystyle{B \sim B_{1}(z^{2}) \sim \big (z^{2} \circ \varphi _{ a^{2}}\big)(z^{2}).}$$
Thus,
$$\displaystyle{B \sim \varphi _{a}^{2}\varphi _{ -a}^{2} \sim z^{2}\big(\varphi _{ -a} \circ \varphi _{a}\big)^{2},}$$
which shows that there is some b ≠ 0 such that B ∼ z 2 φ
b
2. The proof is complete. □

Para.Emphasis: Suppose B is a finite Blaschke product of order 4. If B ∼ z

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Suppose B is a finite Blaschke product of order 4. Consider the number q of components of S
B . There are several cases under consideration: q = 2, 3 and 4.

If
$$q = 4 =\mathrm{ order}\,B$$
, then for each local inverse ρ of B, ♯[ρ] = 1, which implies that ρ is single-valued and holomorphic in
$$\mathbb{D} - F$$
for some finite subset F of
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. Since ρ is bounded by 1, it extends analytically to
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. Since B ∘ρ = B, ρ is a proper map from
$$\mathbb{D}$$
to
$$\mathbb{D}$$
. Then it follows from Theorem 2.1.3
that
$$\rho \in \mathrm{ Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
. By the proof of Proposition 5.3.6 B has the following form: B = m(φ
λ
4) for some
$$m \in \mathrm{ Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
. Therefore, B ∼ z 4. Since S
B has four components, then
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) = 4$$
.

To complete the proof, we will show that
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) = 3$$
if and only if B ∼ z 2 φ
λ
2(λ ≠ 0). To see this, we first claim that the following are equivalent.
(i)
There is a Blaschke product B 1 of order 2 such that B ∼ B 1 ∘ z 2 and B ≁ z 4.
(ii)
B ∼ z 2 φ
λ
2 for some λ ≠ 0.

(ii) ⇒ (i) follows directly from Lemma 5.8.8. To see (i) ⇒ (ii), assume that there is some Blaschke product B 1 of order 2 such that B ∼ B 1 ∘ z 2 and B ≁ z 4. Note that there is some
$$h \in \mathrm{ Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
such that
$$\displaystyle{h \circ B_{1} =\xi z\varphi _{a}(z)}$$
for some nonzero
$$a \in \mathbb{D}$$
and | ξ | = 1. Then B ∼ z 2 φ
a (z 2), and by Lemma 5.8.8 B ∼ z 2 φ
λ
2 for some λ ≠ 0. Therefore, (i) and (ii) are equivalent.

If B ∼ z 2 φ
λ
2(λ ≠ 0), then by Proposition 5.8.5 q = 3, forcing
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) = 3$$
.

Conversely, assume that
$$\dim \mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B) = q = 3$$
. It suffices to show that there is some Blaschke product B 1 of order 2 such that B ∼ B 1(z 2) and B ≁ z 4. Since q = 3, then we may assume that all components of S
B are G[z], G[ρ 1] and G[ρ 2], where ♯[ρ 1] = 1 and ♯[ρ 2] = 2. As discussed above, ρ 1 is a member in
$$\mathrm{Aut}(\mathbb{D})$$
different from id. By a similar version of Proposition 5.3.6 or [DSZ, Lemma 8.1], we get B ∼ B 1(z 2) for some Blaschke product B 1. Clearly, B ≁ z 4.
The proof is complete. □

Section1.Para: By using somewhat different methods based on partition of the local inverses of B, arithmetics of reducing subspace are available when the order of B is not large [DPW]. In particular, [DPW, Theorem 4.2] gives a complete characterization for the numbers of minimal reducing subspaces when order B = 8.

Section1.Heading: Remarks on Chap. 5
Section1.Para: Most materials of this chapter come from Guo and Huang’s paper [GH4].

All discussions in this chapter are based on the Bergman space
$$L_{a}^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
. We obtain a complete classification for thin Blaschke product B such that
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is nontrivial. Also, we construct a first example of a Blaschke product B for which
$$\mathcal{V}^{{\ast}}(B)$$
is trivial; equivalently, M
B is irreducible. This gives a negative answer to the following problem:

Para.Emphasis: For each infinite Blaschke product B, does M
always have a nontrivial reducing subspace?

Section1.Para:
This problem is of interest in at least two aspects. Firstly, for a finite product B different from the Möbius map, M
B always has a nontrivial reducing subspace [HSXY]. Secondly, on the Hardy space
$$H^{2}(\mathbb{D})$$
M
B always has a nontrivial reducing subspaces if B is any Blashcke product different from the Möbius map.
Section 5.1 of this chapter introduces some necessary preliminaries. Propositions 5.1.1, 5.1.3 and Lemma 5.1.2 are probably known [GH4].
In [GH4], Guo and Huang proved Lemmas 5.2.2, 5.2.3 and Theorems 5.2.4, 5.2.5. Lemmas 5.2.1, 5.2.6, Propositions 5.2.7 and 5.2.8 appeared also in [GH4].

Theorems 5.4.1, Corollaries 5.4.10, 5.4.5, Proposition 5.4.4, Lemma 5.4.8 come from [GH4]. The gluable property is crucial in this chapter, and Definitions 5.4.2, 5.4.3 appeared first in [GH4]. The finite-Blaschke-product version of Proposition 5.3.4 was implied in [DSZ, DPW], though without proof.
Lemma 5.5.1 was proved in [GH4]. Theorems 5.5.3, 5.3.1, Propositions 5.3.2, 5.3.6, Lemma 5.3.3 and Example 5.3.5 come from [GH4]. Also, Lemma 5.6.1 and Example 5.6.3 are proved in [GH4].
Guo and Huang showed Theorems 5.7.1 and 5.7.2. Lemma 5.7.3, Propositions 5.7.4, 5.8.1 and Example 5.8.2 are from [GH4].
Lemma 5.8.3, Examples 5.8.4, 5.8.6 and Proposition 5.8.5 are new.

In Section 5.8 of this chapter we mentioned the work of Douglas et al. [DPW]. They also considered when a finite Blaschke product can be written as the composition of two finite Blaschke products. It is worthy to mention that concerning this question, Cowen wrote an earlier manuscript [Cow5]. He used the techniques of complex analysis and group theory. But the approach and aim in [Cow5] differ a lot from the theme of this chapter. An even earlier paper by Ritt [Ri1] considered the problem of compositional factorization of polynomials and gave the uniqueness of factorization, and this job was later generalized, to some extent, to the case of rational functions by Ritt himself [Ri2].

Concerning reducing subspaces of analytic Toeplitz operators and the question to determine which analytic Toeplitz operators are irreducible, we call the reader’s attention to the following references: [A1, Ba, DW, Nor, T1, T3] and [Zhu1, Zhu2]. Here, we have no intention to include a complete literature.
The authors are grateful to Dr. Xie and Dr. Z. Wang for making nice figures in this chapter.
